abstract.para: This document introduces the key concepts of Information Sharing Planning, provides a reference guide to the Channels Web application, and shows how to apply the ISP Method with Channels to systematically build and analyze information sharing plans. A lexicon of ISP terms and the complete list of detectable ISP issues can be found in the Appendix.

section.title: Why Plan the Sharing of Information?
section.para: Most organizations now operate in complex "ecosystems" where they depend on each other for information critical to their missions. It is common wisdom that getting the right information at the right time is essential to achieving mission success. This is even more so in a connected world where opportunities can be fleeting and risks can spread not only quickly but far and wide.

Yet most organizations do not plan how they should share information within and across organizational boundaries. It is something of a paradox that while they will plan their finances or model their business processes to achieve greater efficiency, they will rarely determine how they need to communicate to better prevent, respond or recover from crises.

Failure to plan how information should flow can cost lives, money, reputation. During a crisis, information will not spontaneously flow as needed, and maintaining contact lists is clearly not enough. Organizations must prepare and create actionable information sharing plans. Information sharing can and should be planned not only in order to be prepared but also to effectively retain and disseminate communication best practices.

para.emphasis: Information Sharing Planning (ISP) models, analyzes and deploys information sharing best practices so that organizations can more effectively mitigate systemic risks and seize opportunities from anticipated events.

section.para: ISP provides a framework and method for designing and improving the information sharing practices required by networked organizations to achieve their missions.

section.title: Why Use Channels to Plan Information Sharing?
section.para: Planners use Channels, a Web application, to jointly build information sharing plans (IS plans). Planning information sharing is done in preparation of anticipated events. Channels is not meant for managing the actual sharing of information during a crisis.
When building IS plans using Channels, planners clarify and uncover:

listitem.para: who needs what information, why, and when
who has or can produce needed information, how, and when
what information should flow, when, and how
flaws in information sharing practices
how people, systems, and organizations should be networked
the consequences of not sharing according to plan
where shared information originally comes from and ultimately ends up

section.title: IS practices and environment
section.para:
Building an IS plan in Channels can be divided into
modeling information sharing practices (IS practices)
profiling the environment (organizations, people, and places) the IS practices apply to

When modeling IS practices, planners describe what kind of people and systems (or agents) are to be assigned to planned tasks. More importantly, planners describe what information would be acquired by the execution of a task and then shared with others who need it to carry out their own tasks. A model of IS would normally not identify task assignees by name, but rather specify them by their roles, qualifications, and/or jurisdictions and by the types of organizations they belong to.

When entering the profiles of people, systems, and organizations into an IS plan, planners do so with the expectation that profiles will match the descriptions of task assignees. Once assigned to a task, an agent can become committed to sharing information acquired by executing the task as specified by the (modeled) IS practices.

All modeling is done via input forms. Some forms (for defining tasks, receives and sends) have both a simple and advanced formats. The simple formats shows the most frequently filled-in subset of all fields.

figure.title: Sample IS modeling form in Channels - Task form (simple)

section.db:para: The advanced format shows all fields.

figure.title: Sample IS modeling form in Channels - Task form (advanced)

section.db:para: A planner can toggle between the simple and advanced format of a form, where applicable.
section.para: From the moment an IS plan is created, it can be visualized, analyzed and diagnosed, albeit to little effect until it has been sufficiently built up.
By using Channels to build IS plans, planners produce:

listitem.para: a reusable, transportable model of informations sharing (best) practices
actionable, personalized information sharing guidelines ( a.k.a protocols - IS practices applied to profiled agents)
information flow analytics and visualizations
detected information sharing gaps, bottlenecks, single points of failure, and other issues

section.para: A model of information sharing practices is visualized primarily as information flow maps where tasks are connected by information sharing flows. Each information flow specifies information sharing commitments agents executing the information-producing task need to make with agents executing the information-consuming task.

section.title: Issue detection
section.para: Channels automatically detects issues in an IS plan (upwards of 100 different types of issues). Issues are communicated to planners visually (tasks and flows drawn in red) and in other ways as well (issues panels throughout, all-issues table, issues summary report). The entire set of outstanding issues is recalculated with every change planners make to the plan. Planners can manually indicate issues that Channels cannot detect, usually because the specific issues involve domain knowledge.

An issue has a description, a list of suggested remediations, and a severity level (minor, major, severe, extreme). The severity of an issue is either a constant for the type of issue, or it is calculated from the potential cascade of task failures attributable to the issue, in which case the severity is set by the most severe risk not mitigated or the most valuable gain not realized because of the failure.

figure.title: Examples of issue detection and reporting

section.title: Failure impact analysis
section.para: Issue diagnostics is one of many kinds of analysis Channels performs on an IS plan. Another is failure impact analysis. Channels can show what would happen should a planned task not be performed or should some information not be shared as planned.

section.title: Dissemination analysis
section.para:
Channels can answer other questions about IS practices once they have been captured into an IS model:
Where would an element for information come from or end up according to plan?
Would it arrive in time?
How is it transformed along the way?

section.title: Information sharing guidelines
section.para: Channels applies the modeled IS practices to actual people and systems based on the roles they play in organizations. The results are personalized IS guidelines that can be accessed online by participants in the plan and printed.

section.title: Required networking
section.para: By applying modeled IS practices to known people and systems in organizations, Channels can determine how organizations ought to be networked for an IS plan to be realized.

figure.title: An organization's network based on an IS plan

section.title: Information sharing should also be planned
section.para: While the effort required to model IS practices far exceeds that of simply drawing information flow maps using a drawing tool, the benefits of modeling IS practices using Channels are substantial and include the automated generation of personalized IS guidelines, issue detection, and analyses that illuminate the properties and consequences of applying these practices.
Channels is to information sharing what spreadsheets are to financial planning, and what Business Process Modeling is to business operations.

section.title: Information sharing plan
section.db:para: In order to productively use Channels, a planner must first have a clear, conceptual understanding of Information Sharing Planning.
section.para: An Information Sharing Plan (IS Plan) specifies the information sharing commitments required of people and systems (agents) in roles of responsibility to fulfill the missions of their organizations, before, during, and/or after events that test their missions.

Agents achieve goals that fulfill their organizations' missions by executing, individually or as teams, tasks that are assigned to them. By executing their assigned tasks, agents directly manage risks, achieve gains, and/or produce information needed by other tasks. Information sharing flows connect tasks that produce information with tasks that need it. Information can be shared between people, people and systems, or between systems, over transmission media or face-to-face. Sharing can be subject to policies.

When planners define a task, they either identify or characterize the agents to be assigned to it. Characterizing task assignees can be done more or less broadly by specifying them in terms of their organizations, roles, qualifications and/or jurisdictions. Agents can be bound by information sharing commitments whenever they are assigned to tasks that are connected by flows to other tasks. Agents commit to share information they acquire when doing a task with some or all agents who execute flow-connected tasks. Recipient agents implicitly agree not to use the information for other purposes.

It is important to understand that an information sharing plan is not an action plan. Unlike Business Process Modeling, the objective of Information Sharing Planning (ISP) is not to optimize, script, or automate activities. The overarching objective of building an IS plan is to ensure that information does flow as required in order to successfully manage risks and capture opportunities.

Task precedence is however not entirely absent from an IS plan. A task triggered by information requires the prior execution of another task producing it. Such precedence constraints do not typically apply to all tasks in an IS plan, and thus an IS plan will most often not dictate a unique sequence for all tasks.

This is a good thing. Attempting to define a precisely orchestrated action plan for organizations without a central authority is almost always an exercise in futility. So, while an IS plan certainly captures what needs to be done, the focus is squarely on how information needs to flow to ensure that mission-accomplishing tasks are successful. The details of exactly how these tasks are to be executed is currently outside the scope of an ISP model.

section.title: IS plan = IS practices + environment
section.para: An IS plan can be understood as applying information sharing practices to an environment. Information sharing practices are definitions of information-producing and consuming tasks connected by information flows. An environment enumerates agents (people and systems) in roles of responsibility within organizations. These agents are assigned to flow-connected tasks and, as a consequence, have information sharing commitments.

figure.title: Flow-connected tasks in the IS practices model of an IS plan

section.para: In order to separate (decouple) IS practices and environment, it is recommended to model IS practices without mentioning actual organizations, people, or systems when characterizing task assignees. It is best to define tasks as being executed by "disembodied" roles from types of organizations (e.g. a "forensic autopsy" is to be carried by a "coroner" from a "county health office"). IS practices models that are not attached to a particular environment can be applied, possibly with some local adaptations, to more than one environment.

figure.title: Profile of an actual organization populating the environment of an IS plan

section.para: An IS plan's environment identifies the actual people or systems that play the organizational roles mentioned in the IS practices model (or IS model for short). For example, planners could build an IS model for responding to an epidemic outbreak at the state level, and then apply the same IS model to different states, each state being a different environment with its own organizations and role-assigned agents.

Note that there is not yet explicit support in the current release of Channels for separately managing the IS model and environment of an IS plan, or for explicitly composing IS plans by applying one reusable IS model to different environments. A future release of Channels will provide such support. In the meanwhile, planners are strongly encouraged to follow the above best practice of keeping the IS model as decoupled as possible from the IS plan's environment.

section.title: Plan scope: requirements, event phases, goals, and segments
What is the scope of an IS plan?
section.para: The scope of an IS plan is primarily set by 1- identifying the events of significance the plan must address, 2- identifying the organizations and their agents that participate in the plan, and 3- specifying via information sharing requirements the information sharing commitments expected between participating organizations (see "Scoping a Plan" in the "Activities" section of the "ISP Method" chapter) .

section.title: Information sharing requirements
section.db:para: When Planners define IS requirements on a plan, Channels determines which requirements apply to each pair of participating organizations. The outcome is the IS commitments "network" that the IS plan is expected to produce. Channels also compares the IS commitments computed from the plan against the expected network to evaluate how well each organization satisfies the requirements that apply to it.

section.title: Events in scope
section.para: An IS plan of manageable scope normally addresses only a limited number of anticipated events. An event of significance (or event, for short) is something that changes the state of the world for some time in ways that challenge the mission of one or more organizations by introducing risks or by creating opportunities for gains. Organizations assign their agents to tasks that mitigate these risks or make these gains. An event can bring different risks or opportunities to different organizations. For example, an explosion at a refinery, clearly an event of significance, would endanger the lives of workers, would likely cause financial losses to insurers, but could also create an opportunity for commodity traders to profit financially.

The events in an IS plan are not actual events that did or could occur at specific times and locations. Channels is, after all, strictly meant for planning, not for managing ongoing responses. Events in Channels are implicitly types of events that might happen in some indeterminate future, in some location that can be either identified (e.g., in New York City) or specified (e.g., in a large urban area).

section.title: Risk and gains
section.para: Risks and opportunities can be addressed in the time before, during, or after phases of an event (event phases). Typically the purpose of tasks and information sharing in a "before" phase of an event will be to cause or prevent events. Tasks and information sharing planned for a "during" phase of an event will normally be about responding to the event as it is unfolding in order to minimize its negative consequences or maximize positive outcomes. In an "after" phase, it will often be about recovering from the aftermath of an event, or reaping its rewards.

section.title: Controlling scope
section.para: An IS plan will typically focus on at least one, and at most a few, events of significance, and concern itself with one or more phases for each of these events. Events within the scope of a plan are a combination of events that happen outside the control of the participants of the plan (so-called incidents) and of events caused by planned tasks (and thus under the control of participants).

figure.title: Events in the scope of an IS plan

section.para: An IS plan should also address only a small, manageable number of organizational risks or opportunities stemming from events in scope. It is recommended, when starting on a new IS plan, not to involve too many organizations having too many goals in too many phases of too many events. It is better to start small and focused and then grow only as needed.

section.title: Segments: Divide and conquer
section.para: Information sharing plans typically deal with more than one event phase, and they can involve a sizable number of organizations. Because plans can become quite large, planners break them into smaller, more manageable units of planning called segments. When an IS plan is created, it is given a first segment that, by default, responds to an unnamed event. An IS plan always has at least one segment and planners always work within one segment or another.

Each IS plan segment covers one scenario, namely, one phase of one event, possibly in the context of some other past or currents events. For example, a segment might address responding to a "stock price rally" during "a volatile market" and after a prior "hostile takeover attempt".

A segment might put in scope only some of the organizational risks and gain opportunities associated with the scenario it covers. In other words, more than one segment may cover to the same scenario butwith each segment addressing a different list of organizational goals. Two segments should not address the same goal for the same scenario.

figure.title: Organizational goals addressed in a segment

section.para: A segment is expected to address one or more organizational goals stemming from the scenario. A goal is either a risk to an organization (or type of organization) to be mitigated, or a gain to be realized by an organization (or type of organization). Each risk is categorized from a list of types of risks derived from combining actuarial risk management taxonomies. Each gain is also categorized from a list that is the "mirror image" of the risk types. Risks are rated as minor, major, severe, or extreme. Gains are rated as low, medium, high, or highest. Planners can indicate if a risk is implicitly mitigated or a gain implicitly realized when the scenario covered by the segment concludes.

A task or flow in an IS plan belongs to one and only one segment. A segment should contain all the flow-enabled tasks that directly achieve the segment's goals, plus flows and tasks the goal-achieving tasks depend on, directly or indirectly to start, terminate, or succeed.

Segments are normally not disconnected; flows usually connect one or more tasks in one segment to tasks in another. Furthermore a task in one segment might initiate the scenario addressed by the other segment either by causing an event or by terminating it. Initiation of an event marks the beginning of the "during" phase of that event and marks the end of its "before" phase. Termination of an event marks the start of the "after" phase of that event (for example, terminating a fire event starts the fire recovery phase).

figure.title: The inter-connected segments in an IS plan

section.title: Tasks
section.para: Flows (short for information sharing flows) and the tasks they connect are the building blocks of the IS practices model in an IS plan.

A task describes an action to be carried out at some location and for some purpose by one or more agents. Agents assigned to tasks fulfill the responsibilities of the roles bestowed upon them by organizations that employ them.

The agents that ought to be assigned to a task are described by any combination of name, role, jurisdiction, and organization. Ideally, the agents of a task will not be identified but profiled (for example, by role and type of organization only) in the definition of the task so that more than one person or system, but only the intended ones, will match the profile and get assigned to the task.

According to a task's definition, those assigned to the task are expected to carry it out either as a team or on their own. The timing aspects of a task execution can be given, namely, how long the task takes to complete and how soon it repeats, if at all. A task might cause or prevent an event.
Tasks are considered useful if they:

listitem.para: directly achieve goals (mitigate risks or capture gains)
initiate or terminate (phases of) events
or produce information needed by other useful tasks (producing information for tasks that are not themselves useful is not considered useful)

section.para: Tasks can be ongoing, or they can be triggered or terminated by:

listitem.para: direct awareness of events (started, terminated or anticipated)
receiving notifications (or by discovering information which is represented as a notification to self)
receiving requests for information

section.title: Flows
section.para: An information flow links a task that produces information to a task that consumes it. A flow is characterized by:

listitem.para: whether the flow is a notification (sent, received), a request, or a reply
the information communicated, down to its elements, each with optional secrecy classifications and sourcing and handling instructions
whether the situation (event phase and event context) in which the source task is being executed (e.g., responding to a suspected attack) is also to be communicated
the intent of the flow (alarm, announcement, command, feedback or report)
whether the flow is conditional on task failure
the mode of communication (request vs. notification, unicast vs. multicast vs. broadcast)
restrictions, if any, based on shared organization membership or location of the source and/or target of the flow
a list of preferred transmission media (phone, face-to-face, etc.)
the urgency (maximum delay from earliest availability if a notification, or maximum delay from request if a reply)
the impacts, if any, the communication may have (it might trigger or terminate a task)
whether to bypass an intermediate if necessary
whether receipt confirmation is requested
instructions on how to carry out the task
policies that mandate or prohibit sharing

section.title: Information needs
section.para: A task can have information needs (information agents require to execute the task), information capabilities (information acquired by the execution of the task that can then be shared), or both. An information flow implicitly specifies an information need of the receiving task and implicitly specifies an information capability of the sending task. Unless one or more matching information needs are defined on the receiving task, a flow always satisfies the information need it implies. Planners can explicitly define the information needs and capabilities of a task.

Explicitly specifying an information need of a task allows Channels to automatically verify if the need is satisfied (Are all elements supplied in a timely manner by incoming flows?) and to find information-capable tasks that could be connected by flows to satisfy an information need.

figure.title: An information need appears in a flow map as a flow without a source task

section.title: Information capabilities
section.para: Specifying an explicit information capability allows Channels to automatically verify if the sharing capability is being exercised and to find tasks to connect to so that the capability might satisfy their needs.

figure.title: An information capability appears in a flow map as a flow with no target task

section.title: Entities
section.para: An IS plan references by name various agents, places, roles, organizations, events, transmission media and phases of events. These are referred to in ISP as entities. An ISP entity is anything that can be named in an IS plan but is neither a task nor information (or an element thereof). An ISP entity is always unambiguously referenced by name in a plan, its segments, tasks, and flows, or in the profiles of other entities. There can only be one agent named "John Doe", only one event named "Lawsuit filed," etc. in a given plan.

db:section.title: Actual vs type
db:section.para: There are actual entities and there are types of entities. Actual entities (“Jane Smith”, “ACME Inc.”, “Morristown, Morris County, NJ, USA,” etc.) are categorized by types of entities (“Senior executive”, “Corporation”, “City” etc.). Entity types can refine other entity types (a “Senior executive” is a kind of “Executive” which is a kind of "Employee").

Actual entities can be categorized by entity types of the same kind (agents are categorized by agent types etc.) but entity types themselves can be categorized by other entity types, thus forming implicit typologies.

section.title: Agents
section.para: An agent is either a person or an information system (system for short). An agent is capable of sending or receiving notifications and sending and answering queries. An agent has contact information and availability (24/7 by default). An agent's clearance is a list of secrecy classifications (e.g., NATO Top Secret and US Gov. Secret). An agent can communicate in one or languages (if none are given, the agent can communicate in the IS plan's default language).

An agent type can be thought of as a qualification that can be shared by different agents (e.g., "Adult" or "Registered driver"). An agent type is not to be confused with a role. A role implies responsibilities, whereas an agent type denotes qualifications or status.
An agent can be flagged as a system (non-human).
section.db:para: Users participate in a plan when they are associated with one or more agents in that plan. The profile of an agent sets the modalities for associating users to the agent.

If participation as the agent is open to all users of the plan, then any user can effect the association. If not, only planners can do so. The ability of a user to participate as an "open" agent can be restricted to users already associated to another agent with a common employer. For example, the " An ACME floor warden" agent should only be open to users participating as another agent employed by ACME.

An agent can be restricted to having only one user associated with it. Otherwise, any number of users can participate as that agent. For example, any number of users should be able to participate as the "A citizen of New York City" agent.
section.para: The agent's profile can indicate that the users participating as the agent are indistinguishable from each other (for example, call center operators), that is, they participate anonymously. Anonymous participation means that the identities and the personal contact information of the users are not added to the plan's environment and thus do not appear in information sharing guidelines.

section.title: Organizations
section.para: An organization is a group of agents organized to accomplish a common mission. An organization assigns roles of responsibility to the persons and systems that act on its behalf. An organization has contact information and may contain other organizations.

An organization may have information sharing agreements with other organizations to formalize the sharing commitments its members have with members of other organizations. Organizations are referenced in the definitions of a plan itself (organizations that are expected to participate), in segments (organizational risks), tasks, and as parents of other organizations.
Unless indicated otherwise, a organization supports all the transmission media defined in the plan.

section.title: Roles
section.para: A role is a set of powers and responsibilities bestowed by an organization upon an agent acting on behalf of the organization. A role assigned to an agent may be restricted to a jurisdiction (a place). A role is always an entity type. Roles are referenced primarily in task definitions and in organization profiles (the roles played by their employed agents).

section.title: Places
section.para: A place is either a geographical area (some city, county, state, country, natural preserve, etc.) or a known location (some train station, building, etc.). A place can be contained in another (for example, a building can be in a campus). Places are referenced in a plan's definition (the plan's default locale), in events (an event and an event type can both be located to a place), in tasks (location of execution and jurisdiction of assignees), and in organizations (address and jurisdictions of members).

section.title: Events
section.para: An event names a usually transient change in the world that tests the missions of organizations because it introduces risks to these organizations or presents them with opportunities for gains, or both. An event is always an entity type.
Events are referenced in a plan's definition (events in scope), in segments (event phase in focus and event phases in context - scenarios), and in task definitions (events initiated).

section.title: Phases
section.para: A phase names a time period relative to events. A phase is either set to before, during, or after events. Typical phases are “Preparing,” “Responding,” and “Recovering”. A phase is always an entity type. Phases are referenced in a plan's definition (phases in scope), and in segments (event phase in focus and event phases in context).

section.title: Transmission medium
section.para: A transmission medium is a means by which agents transmit information with each other. Transmission media may or may not be technology-based. A medium is either unicast (transmits to a single, known agent), multicast (transmits at once to multiple, known agents), or broadcast (little to no control over the potential multitude who receive the transmission).

A transmission medium can delegate transmissions to other media. For example, VoIP can interface with Telephones. The security of a medium is expressed in terms of secrecy classifications. A transmission medium is always an entity type. Transmission media are referenced in the definitions of communication channels. Communication channels are used to define information flows, needs and capabilities, and the contact information of agents and organizations.
section.db:para: The operation of a transmission medium may require qualifications defined as a type of agent (for example, "certified secure radio operator").

section.title: Secrecy, security and clearances
section.para: Planners can define one or more classification systems in an IS plan and make use of them classify elements of information, define transmission media security, and to set the security clearances of (actual) agents.
A secrecy classification has a name (e.g. “NATO”) and an ordered list of secrecy levels (“Restricted,” “Confidential,” “Secret,” “Focal Top Secret,”and “Cosmic Top Secret”).
Each classification system has a unique name and consists of a list of classification levels ranked from lowest (bottom) to highest (top).
Agents can be given security clearances. Clearances are expressed as classification levels (no more than one per classification system).
The highest classification level of the information it can transmit without infringing upon security requirements determines how secure a transmission medium is.

Information to be shared or needed can be detailed in terms of its essential elements. Elements of information can each be given classification levels, as well as indications of the source and special handling instructions.
Secrecy and security issues that are automatically detected include:

listitem.para: Classified information transmitted over an insufficiently secure channel
A commitment to share classified information with an agent who has insufficient clearances
Receiving classified information and then disseminating it with reduced classification

section.title: The meaning of information in ISP
section.para: As discussed above, tasks and flows are defined in terms of information needed, uncovered and shared. Information is named and is broken into atomic elements. Each element of information is named, can be given security classifications and can be annotated with a description and handling instructions.

Elements of information sent from a task can be described as the result of transforming elements received in the execution of the task. An element of information (EOI) sent can be the same as an EOI received, or it can be an EOI that was received and then renamed, or it can be an aggregation of EOIs received (for example a count, a synthesis,etc.).

An element of information is considered atomic for the purposes of a plan; it is the indivisible unit of transmission and transformation. The EOIs that are aggregated into another EOI can not be later "split apart".

The plurality of an element is left ambiguous. For example, if "suspicious activity report" information contains the element "suspect profile," then it is possible that there will be more than one suspect profile in a report.

When analyzing flows, Channels is not concerned with what the information actually means. For example, Channels does not know what "flight status" means as it has no domain knowledge. Rather, it cares about whether or not two flows concern the same information, and whether an element of information is the same as, or is the transformation of, another element of information.

If the information in two flows have the same name, it does not necessarily mean that they represent, conceptually, the same information. Two tasks performed respectively by a EOC commander and a corporate CEO might both need a "situation assessment," but they would likely not need the same kind of situation assessment with the same elements of information (even if the elements themselves have identical names!).

In Channels, identically named flows, needs, and capabilities (uppercase vs. lowercase and extra spaces are ignored) are explicitly meant to represent the same kind of information (they are synonymous) if and only if they connect to a common task (one flow may be a "send" and the other one a "receive"). Similarly, identically named elements of information are meant to represent the same atom of information if only if the information they compose have the same meaning.

Agents executing a task receive and send information. The information they receive and send may have different names yet have common elements of information. For example, the "suspect profile" element of a sent "suspicious activity report" may be the same as the "suspect description" element of a received "security tip", and it may be the same as the "suspect profile" of received "BOLO" information.

Alternately, an element sent may aggregate elements received. Aggregation combines many elements into a single element, with loss of data. For example, a "suspects count" element aggregates "suspect profile" elements into a single number, losing the details of the individual profiles. Counting is only one of many possible kinds of aggregation. A "threat level," for example, might aggregate a great deal of different elements into a color-coded rating.

In order to track the dissemination of information, it is necessary to indicate when sent elements are the result of the renaming or aggregating of received elements. Channels need only differentiate between those two kinds of element transformation in order to track the dissemination of information. The description field of an element of information can be used to provide more details about the specific nature of an aggregation.

Issue detection takes element renaming and aggregation into account. For example, while it may be acceptable to declassify aggregated elements, it is not acceptable to declassify a renamed, classified element.

section.title: Task assignments and information sharing commitments
ISP is all about commitment
section.db:para: Information sharing planning with Channels boils down to specifying and generating the information sharing commitments that organizations need to successfully carry out their missions in anticipated scenarios. Note that these scenarios can be in any domain of human endeavor and that can be as generic or specific as desired.

section.title: Task assignments
section.db:para: Information sharing commitments are derived by first assigning agents to tasks and then by "networking" these agents according to the information sharing flows that inter-connect the tasks they are assigned to.
section.para: A task in an IS plan is a specification of some action to be done or some decision to be made either all the time, upon witnessing the start or end of an event, upon receiving a notification or a request for information, or upon discovering some new information. In defining a task, planners normally will not identify by name the actual agents to be assigned to it. Planners will most often characterize the agents to be assigned to the task in terms of their qualifications (as agent types), roles, jurisdictions (as named places or types of places), and/or organizations (by name or by type).

A task definition will most often profile the agents that ought to be assigned to it instead of outright naming them. This profiling of assignable agents is best done in terms of roles and organization types. Such assignment profiles will then match agents known to the plan based on their qualifications and employments. Agents that have jobs with participating organizations are assigned to a task if, thanks to their profiles and their employments, they match the agent characterization in the task's definition. For each task defined, all agents within the scope of the plan are examined to see if they match and are to be assigned to the task. This calculation is done (very efficiently) whenever a change is made to the plan.

Let's say a task is defined as to be carried out by all Employees (a role) at a Government Agency (a type of organization). Let's also say that the FBI (an actual organization) is categorized as both a "Law Enforcement Agency" and "Federal Agency", and that "Federal Agency" is categorized as a "Government Agency". Let's also say that a manager is a kind of employee. Then agents employed by the FBI as managers could be assigned to the task.

section.title: Information sharing commitments
section.para: Any agent assigned to a task that sends information to another task (i.e. is connected by a flow targeting the other task) commits to share it with some or all agents assigned to the task receiving the information. A task assigned to three agents with a flow targeting another task assigned to two agents could imply six different information sharing commitments, one from each assignee of the information-producing task to each assignee of the information-consuming task.

If the flow is annotated as "to every", then the commitment is to share it with all assignees of the target task, otherwise the flow is "to any" and the commitment is to share with at least one of the assignees of the target task.

Not all assignees of the "target task" are necessarily eligible to be the beneficiaries of information sharing commitments (commitments, for short) of each agent assigned to the "source" task. Commitments can be subject to restrictions or prohibitions. Commitments between agents can be restricted to agents in the same or different organization or in organizations with the same parent organizations. They can be restricted to agents in the same location or different location, to agents who are supervisors. Commitments can even be restricted to one self, which may sound odd until one realizes that an agent might uncover information doing a task, keep it to oneself and start another task on the basis of this information (an agent has in essence notified itself to trigger another task of his). Commitments can also be restricted to "someone else" or to agents in both the same organization and location.

figure.title: Sharing commitments derived from assignments to tasks connected by a flow

section.para: A flow can be marked as "prohibited", in which case no commitments are implied, no matter who is assigned to the source and target tasks. Flow prohibition is used to specify "exceptions to the rules" in IS plans. (More on that later.)

section.title: Information sharing procedures
section.para: An agent's information sharing procedures (aka protocols aka guidelines) is the list of all task assignments for the agent plus all associated IS commitments computed by Channels for that agent. An agent gets his/her IS procedures from Channels in the form of IS guidelines.

Many analytics in Channels (requirement satisfaction, dissemination, impact failure, network, various type of issues) depend on the computing of IS commitments for all agents in an IS plan. Because matching of profiles involves entity types refining other entity types, the proper design of typologies (for agents, roles, places, organizations etc.) is key to building IS plans that generate the desired IS procedures.

section.title: Expressing exceptions by overriding tasks and flows
section.para: It is at times necessary to express "exceptions to the rule" when modeling IS practices. For example, IS practices might dictate that all employees alert their supervisors if they become aware of suspicious activities, whereas managers, who are also employees, should not alert their supervisors but rather directly contact the head of security.

Such exceptions in IS practices can be captured by defining overriding tasks and by defining prohibited flows from the overriding tasks that are otherwise equivalent to flows from the overridden tasks.

figure.title: Overriding tasks and flows to express exceptions in IS practices

section.para: When a task (for example, "managers detecting threats") overrides another task ("employees detecting threats" - all managers being employees) , agents assigned to the overriding task (managers...) are not assigned to the overridden task (managers are no assigned to the overridden employee's task). The overriding task represents the exception to the rule represented by the overridden task.

Furthermore, if a task is annotated as "prohibited," then no agent is assigned to this task. If the prohibited task overrides another task, only the agents assignable to the overridden task that could not be assigned to the overriding task, were it not prohibited, are assigned to it. This allows planners to express exceptions such as "all employees leave the building except for managers who are prohibited from leaving the building".

A flow A overrides another flow B if:
they both have the same name (discounting case and extra blanks)
the source task of flow A overrides the source task of flow B
and the target task of flow A is the same as or overrides the target of flow B

If an agent has sharing commitments computed from the overriding (more speicific) flow A then they replace any and all commitments for this agent that are computed from the overridden (less specific) flow B. Furthermore, if overriding flow A is prohibited, then whoever would have commitments from flow A has commitments from neither flow A nor from overridden flow B.

section.title: Information sharing agreements
section.para: A confirmed information sharing agreement is a formal recognition by an organization that information sharing commitments with other organizations covered by the agreement are formally endorsed, preferably as documented by an attached Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). A sharing commitment is by one (actual) organization toward another (actual) organization and is about sharing a certain kind of information (with essential elements) for a given purpose (task).

Potential information sharing agreements are implied in the cross-organizational information sharing commitments that Channels dynamically generates. Potential sharing agreements are recomputed everytime the commitments (also computed) change because of modifications to the plan. A sharing agreement becomes permanent when it is confirmed.

Channels discovers implied, to-be-confirmed sharing agreements by aggregating similar commitments that cross organizational lines into "information sharing relationships". Each information sharing relationship is a summary of sharing commitments for the same information (the agents in the commitments and their roles are abstracted out). For example, an information sharing relationship would summarize the fact that members of Bank A commit to share fraud information with members of Bank B. For each such relationship, a (potential) sharing agreement is produced and planners can indicate whether an information sharing agreement has been formalized, and attach or link to the MOU document formalizing the agreement.

figure.title: The sharing agreements of an organization

section.para: An organization may require that all its sharing commitments with other organizations be covered by sharing agreements. If a cross-organizational agreement falls under a non-confirmed agreement, an issue is raised by Channels. Furthermore, if a sharing agreement is confirmed but not documented, an issue is also raised. Note that in applying these constraints, Channels does not distinguish whether both organizations belong to a common parent organization or not.

section.title: Descriptions, instructions and attachments
section.para: Not everything in the definition of an IS plan can be captured neatly as "structured data". Some important data is best conveyed with free form text or via attached documents.

Most forms used to define elements of an IS plan contain a text field called "description" where planners can optionally enter explanatory or documentary text. Instead of a description field, tasks and flows have instruction fields. Organizations also have mission statement fields. Descriptions, instructions and mission statements are not examined by Channels (Channels is indifferent to their content) but they can appear in reports,such as the IS guidelines, that Channels produces.

figure.title: A segment, like most elements of an IS plan, has a description

section.para: Sometimes an element of a plan or the plan itself can be documented by a PDF or a Web page or illustrated by a photo or a video. Channels allows planners to attach documents to a plan element by uploading them or linking to them in the context of that element.

An attachment is optionally given a name (its URL is the default name). It is also given a type. Different kinds of plan elements allow different kinds of attachment types. Certain types of attachments have different properties.

The types of attachments recognized by Channels are:
Reference - Reference documentation. Movies or graphics attached to tasks and flows as references are highlighted as icons that, when clicked, show the graphic or video, assuming that the Web browser supports the media type.
Media reference attachment
Picture - A picture document is used to produce icons displayed in flow maps. Channels automatically converts pictures into icons it uses in various visualizations. Only one picture per plan element is allowed.
Picture attachment and use as icon
Policy - Document containing policy statements participants need to be aware of.
Mandating policy - Document containing policy statements that mandate tasks or flows.
Forbidding (prohibiting) policy - Document containing policy statements that restrict tasks or flows. Note that attaching a prohibiting policy document to a flow or a task does not in and of itself prohibit it. The policy might prohibit execution of the task or of the flow only in some but not all circumstances (and in ways too complex to be captured formally in the IS plan). To prohibit a flow or a task in an IS plan, planners must explicitly mark it as prohibited (via a check box in the task or flow form).
Prohibiting policy attachment and prohibited flow
MOU - Memorandum of understanding documenting sharing agreements.
Tags - Predefined tags (see next section), attachable to an IS plan as a whole.
Info standards - Predefined elements of information implied by tags, attachable to an IS plan as a whole.
Help - When a Help document is attached to a plan (in the plan details panel accessed from Show/About plan), it becomes the online help accessed from the Home page.

section.title: Tagging
section.para: Tags provide a useful mechanism for the ad hoc cataloging of elements of an IS plan that otherwise may have nothing else in common. Most elements of a plan can be tagged. An element can have multiple, comma-separated tags.
A planner can see all the tags used in an IS plan and look up all elements of the plan tagged with a given tag.

The set of all tags in an IS plan is called the tag domain. Tags can be grouped by named sub-domains. When a tag belongs to a sub-domain, the tag is written as the name of the sub-domain followed by a colon followed by the name of the tag. For example, "esf:transportation" is the tag "transportation" in the tag sub-domain "esf".

A planner can easily look up all elements tagged with tags belonging to a given sub-domain. Tag sub-domains can be predefined and attached to an IS plan (an attachment of type "Tag") prior to the tags being used. Note that tags need not be predefined to be used in tagging plan elements. Files defining tag sub-domains attached to an IS plan

A special kind of tag sub-domain is called an "information standard". Each information standard tag is associated with a list of predefined elements of information, each with a name, and optional description and handling instructions. When a flow is tagged with an information standard tag, its elements of information can be auto-populated with those associated with the tag. An information standard tag sub-domain is added to an IS plan by attaching a file defining them (an attachment of type "Info standards").

figure.title: Tagging a flow with an info standard tag to auto-populate its elements of information

section.para: Documents defining basic or info standard tag sub-domains must adhere to simple formatting rules. For basic tag sub-domains, the rules are:

listitem.para: A blank line or line starting with # is ignored.
Each line contains a single fully named tag (e.g. esf:transportation) or comma-separated tags (e.g. esf:transportation, esf:hazmat).

figure.title: File defining basic tags for the "esf" tagging sub-domain

section.para:
For info standard tag sub-domain files, the rules are:
A blank line or line starting with # is ignored.
A tag name is given in full and starts at the beginning of a line.
The elements of information for a tag each appear indented on a separate line beneath the tag.
The optional description and handling instructions are separated each by a hyphen.

figure.title: File defining info standard tags in the "cap" tagging sub-domain

db:section.db:title: Information sharing requirements
db:section.db:para: An IS plan is an IS practices model (task definitions linked by information flows) applied to an IS environment (actual organizations with their agents in roles of responsibility to be assigned to tasks). The resulting IS plan generates IS commitments between agents in the IS environment that are assigned to tasks connected by information sharing flows.
IS requirements are how planners specify what kinds of IS commitments the IS plan is required to produce between participating organizations.

An IS requirement can be defined broadly ("Each organization shall at least share something with each other organization.") or narrowly ("The FBI shall share threat reports with at least two agents in each of the transit security agencies when the threat level is high"). IS requirements can be added to the plan at any time during its construction.

An IS requirement, depending on how it is defined, might apply to all pairings of (actual) organizations, where one organization is the source (or the committer) and the other is the receiver (the beneficiary of the commitment), or it might apply only to a few pairs, or to only one.

A pair of organizations an IS requirement applies to can satisfy the requirement weakly, strongly or not at all, depending on the number and nature of the sharing commitments that "network" the two organizations.
Just as with any other plan element, an IS requirement is given a name and, possibly, a description. Planners can attach documents to a requirement as well as add ad hoc issues about it.

An IS requirement is defined in terms:
the information shared
its name
the names of elements of information (meaningful only if the information is named)
information flow tags
the source
agent (name or type)
role
jurisdiction (name or type)
organization (name or type)
when the information is acquired by the source
task name
task tags
event
before, during, after the event, or any of the above
how many agents in the source organization commit to share
minimum number (zero or more, 1 is the default) - for weak satisfaction
safe number ( same as minimum or greater) - for strong satisfaction
maximum number (the default is no limit)
the beneficiary (same attributes as the source)
when the information is shared with the beneficiary (same attributes as for information acquired by source)
how many agents in the beneficiary organization would receive the information (minimum, safe and maximum numbers)
how many alternate sources is there for each beneficiary agent (minimum, safe and maximum numbers)

Except for the minimum and safe number attributes, all of the defining attributes of an IS requirement can be left empty in order to match any and all values. When all attributes in the definition of requirement are left empty or at their default value, the requirement can be interpreted as "Each organization shall share at least something with each other organization." This "empty" requirement applies to all possible source-beneficiary pairings of organizations in the IS plan.

When analyzing an IS requirement, all possible source-receiver pairs of organizations are identified and only those to which the requirement apply are retained. Then, for each applicable pair, the IS commitments where the "committer" is an agent in the source organization and where the beneficiary is an agent the receiver organization are tallied. The object of the analysis is to see if enough agents in the source organization commit to share, if enough agents in the receiving organization are beneficiaries of the commitments, and if each individual receiving agent has enough committing source agents.
A requirement applies to a pair of organizations formed by source organization A and beneficiary organization B. A requirement applies to source organization A if:

the requirement specifies no source organization
or specifies a matching type of source organization
or specifies the source organization by name
A requirement applies to beneficiary organization B if:
the requirement specifies no beneficiary organization
or specifies a matching type of beneficiary organization
or specifies the beneficiary organization by name
The satisfaction of a requirement is rated as either impossible, negative, weak, or strong.

Each organization in a source-receiver pair might not equally satisfy an applicable IS requirement. The source organization might satisfy the requirement strongly by having at least the safe amount of agents committing to share with agents in the receiving organization. The receiving organization might satisfy the requirement but only weakly because even though it meets the minimum count of beneficiary agents and the minimum count of alternate committing agents per beneficiary agent, it does not meet the safe count in both counts.

The satisfaction of a requirements is considered impossible when there is no flow defined in the plan that could conceivably yield an IS commitment as specified by the requirement. For example, if the IS requirement is about sharing information tagged esf:hazard and not a single flow in the plan is tagged with esf:hazard, then the requirement satisfaction is rated as "impossible".

chapter.title: Using Channels
chapter.para: Channels is a collaborative Web application information sharing planners use to build, analyze and improve information sharing plans (IS plans), and to publish information sharing protocols (aka procedures or guidelines).
A Channels server can host multiple IS plans. Users can be given access to more than one plan hosted on a Channels server.

IS plans are versioned. Each plan has one development version being developed, possibly one production version that can no longer be changed, and zero or more retired versions (prior production versions).

section.title: User Roles
section.para: Channels recognizes three user roles: administrator, planner, and participant.

A Channels server has at least one administrator. An administrator has unlimited rights and privileges over the Channels server and the plans hosted on it. A user is given planner privileges by an administrator for some or all plans on a Channels server. Planners jointly develop, review, and deploy IS plans for which they have been given planner status by an administrator.

Users can be given participant access to some or all plans by an administrator. Participants view their IS guidelines and respond to surveys from planners (currently only about issue resolution). A user can be a planner for some plans, a participant for others, and has no access to plans for which he/she is neither planner nor participant.
An administrator implicitly also has planner privileges over all plans hosted on the Channels server. A planner for a given plan implicitly also has participant privileges.
An administrator of a Channels server can:

listitem.para: configure the Channels server
add new plans
delete existing plans
move a development version of a plan into production, retiring the previous production version, if any
assign users to plans and change their user roles

section.para: A planner of an IS plan (and all administrators) can:

listitem.para: view all non-retired versions of the plan
modify the development version
associate participants with agents (production and development versions only)
view plan analytics
vote with other planners to put the development version into production
launch, access, and close online surveys of selected planners and participants about issues in the plan

section.para: A participant in an IS plan (and all its planners and all administrators) can:

listitem.para: view the IS guidelines report for the agent he/she is associated with
provide feedback about his/her IS guidelines
access and respond to online surveys

if a version of a plan is marked as a "template"
view (but not modify) the details of that version
view all analytics for that version
forward a survey to a non-user and, in the process, grant participant privilege for the plan

section.para: Note that a participant in an IS plan does not have IS guidelines until associated with an agent in the plan. A participant can self-associate to agents that have been marked by planners as "open" agents.

section.title: Channels Pages
section.para: Channels is a Web application composed of a number of Web pages, some of which behave not unlike desktop applications.

The Channels pages are:
The login page
The "renew password" page
The home page
The administration page
The information sharing model page
The issues summary page
The information sharing guidelines page
The information sharing needs page
The surveys page
The feedback page
Various pages that handle login failures, system errors, session timeouts, etc.

section.title: Logging In
section.para: When accessing Channels, an unrecognized user is presented with a login screen. The user is asked to enter user name and password. To avoid being asked to login again after quitting without signing out, the user can check the "Remember me..." check box (the browser must allow cookies for this to work).
Upon successful login, a user is taken to the Channels Home Page.
Note that users can not self-register on a Channels server. They must be added together with their initial passwords by a Channels administrator.

A user who has forgotten his/her password or user id can request a new password. The new password together with a user id reminder is sent via email (the user must remember the email address used when registering him/her into the Channels server).

section.title: Home Page
section.para: The Home page lets the user select a plan from all plans they are authorized to see. A plan is always selected by default upon logging in.
The home pages of administrators, planners, and participants have different content reflecting their differing privileges in regards to the selected plan.
section.db:para: Keep in mind that an administrator is by default also a planner and that a planner is by default also a participant. An administrator can do and see everything a planner can, and a planner can do and see everything that a participant can.

section.title: Administrator's home page
section.para: The administrator's home page is the same as a planner's home page except that the administrator is given access to the administration page.

section.title: Planner's home page
section.para:
A planner can
edit the development version of the plan and view its production version (same interface but edit form fields are disabled for production plans)
view metrics about issues detected in the plan
view all IS guidelines reports (task assignments and information sharing commitments in report format)
View the information needs reports of all participants
Send messages to other planners, and to all users (participants will see these messages as "news")

section.title: Participant's home page
section.para:
A participant in a normal (non-template) plan can
Update name, email address, personal contact info and password
Self-associate (or dissociate) with "open agents" - agents marked by planners as self-assignable by participants - thus generating new IS guidelines
Read messages broadcast to all users (or news) by planners
Access the IS guidelines report generated from the plan's production version for the agent(s) he/she is associated with
Access the information needs report from the plan's production version for the agent(s) he/she is associated with
View, respond to, decline and forward surveys
Send feedback and reply to planner responses
View a calendar of planning-related events maintained by planners

An IS plan can be marked as a template. This indicates that there is nothing sensitive in the plan and that a participant can see not only his/her participation in the plan (personal IS guidelines, info needs report), but also the entire plan itself in its production version, as well as plan analytics. A participant (and all other users) can see but not modify the production version of the plan (production versions of IS plans are always read-only to all users, even administrators).

section.title: Home page collaboration and settings panel
section.para: The collaboration and settings tabs in the home page allow planners to communicate with other users via messages, calendar events, and enables the user to manage personal contact information, password, and associations with open agents (agents marked by planners as self-assignable by participants).

section.title: About me
section.para: The "About Me" tab lets a user edit his/her full name and private email, and change password. If the user is a participant in the plan, the user can update the contact information for the agent he/she has been assigned to.

section.title: What I do
section.db:para: The "What I do" tab shows the agents the participant is associated with. Participants have IS guidelines (aka protocols) and information need reports only if they are associated with agents in the plan. Associations with open agents are under the plarticipant's control. Other associations are under planner control (set from within the plan editor).

section.title: Messages
section.para: Planners (and thus administrators) can both send and receive messages.
Participants can only read the broadcast messages from planners which appear in the "Messages" tab. They cannot reply to or comment on these messages.

section.title: Calendar
section.para: Planners can add events to a Google calendar associated to the plan (as configured by administrators in the Administration Page). Events can be viewed by all users of the plan.

section.title: Feedback panel
section.para: A feedback mechanism is available from the Home page to all users of Channels. It allows users to ask questions, make recommendations, and report problems. The feedback is sent via email to an address configured for the plan by an administrator. The email address of the user sending the feedback is included in the email. Further conversations can take place over email.
Note that feedback can also be sent from within IS guidelines.

section.title: Administration page
section.para: A Channels administrator (and only an administrator) can create new plans, retire existing plans, move the development version of a plan to production (and thus retire the production version if any), and register, disable, and assign per-plan access privileges to users. Administrators are also responsible for configuring the Channels server.

section.title: Plan creation and user privileges
section.para: The Administration page is accessible only to administrators of the Channels server.
section.db:para:
Administrators can
Create new plans
Delete a plan
Put the development version of a plan into production
Configure communications via email and calendar
Add, remove and authorize users

section.title: External services
section.para: Channels relies on a number of external, online services:

listitem.para: Geonames and Google MapsTM for geolocation
An email service (SMTP) to send emails
Google CalendarTM to communicate calendar events of interest to users

section.para: Access to an external service requires account identification, either in the form of user id and password or in the form of an API key. When Channels is used as a service, external service configurations are already taken care of. However when installing a Channels server, an Administrator must acquire access to these external services and configure Channels to use the correct account information.
Planners need to log into Google Calendar to add, edit, or remove calendar events communicated in Channels.

section.title: Google Calendar settings
section.para:
To setup a plan with its dedicated Google Calendar, an administrator must follow these steps:
Open up a Google account
Go to calendar settings and
share the calendar
grab the calendar's private key
grab the calendar's embedded URL (up to the '?' character)
Fill in the calendar configuration fields in the Administration page

figure.title: Calendar embedded URL and private key

section.title: Overview
section.para: The information sharing model page is also known as the Plan Editor. It opens on the version (development or production) of a plan selected in the Home page. A user can select plans for which he/she has planner privileges, unless the plan version is marked as a template in which case the user has access to the read-only production version, if any.

Only the development version of a plan can be modified. A production version is “read-only.” In a read-only version, all form fields are disabled and no survey can be launched about issue resolution. Note that even though non-open participations in a plan can only be modified from the development version of a plan , they also apply to the production version.

When the Plan Editor opens up on (a version of) a plan, Channels pre-selects a segment and a task within it. A segment and a task are always selected. The task with its “receive” and “send” information flows are shown “collapsed” and summarized.

If the plan is brand new, an empty task in the otherwise empty and untitled segment is selected. An empty segment is about "responding" to an "unnamed" event . The last task in a segment cannot be removed. The last segment in a plan cannot be removed. Thus a plan will always have at the very least one segment, one event and one task.

A planner can at any time switch segments, if more than one is defined. The tasks and information flows of the selected segment are visualized as a flow map (tasks connected by information sharing flows). The selected task is highlighted (by a gray outlined rectangle) in the flow map.

The Plan Editor window has four principal components:
The guide panel to the left
The segment bar at the top
The information flow map
The panels showing the selected task with its receives and sends at the bottom
The collaboration tab panels to the right

section.title: The guide panel
section.para: The guide panel gives easy access to key concepts, and to short explanations of how planners can use Channels to build and improve IS plans, with links into the documentation and short cuts to Channels functionality.
section.db:para: The guide panel can be collapsed and can be expanded back from the "show" menu in the segment bar.

section.title: The segment bar
section.para: The segment bar identifies the currently selected segment within the plan. If applicable, a drop down menu gives the planner access to others segments within the plan.
The Help icon opens up this content for browsing in a separate window.

The left and right arrow buttons are Channels' "back and forward" buttons. The back button brings the Plan Editor to its previous state, that is, re-opening whatever panel was just closed or collapsed, showing the previous segment that was just switched from, etc. The forward button brings back the state the planner backed from.

The plan editor uses AJAX to provide a user experience similar to that of a "native" application. The "back and forward" buttons must be used instead of the browser's back and forward button which would navigate users out of the plan editor.

section.title: Show menu
section.para: The segment bar's "Show" menu gives access to:

listitem.para: The guide panel, if collapsed
The collaboration tab panels, if collapsed
The plan details panel
The segment details panel (clicking on the name of the segment is a shortcut to this panel)
The feedback panel (to manage user feedback)
The surveys panel
A map of all segments in the plan
All issues in the plan
The entity typologies panel
The plan index
An interactive visualization of IS procedures produced from the plan
The plan requirements panel
The plan participations panel
Channels Help (this document)

section.title: Actions menu
section.para: The segment bar's "Action" menu enables the planner to act on the segment as a whole by:

listitem.para: Sending a message about the segment
Adding a new task
Adding or pasting a copied task
Adding an ad hoc issue to the segment
Pasting a copied attachment to the segment
Moving tasks from this segment to another

section.para: Other available actions include:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action (if possible)
Redoing the last undone action (if possible)
Removing the current segment from the plan
Logging out of Channels

section.title: Information flow map
section.para: The information flow map displayed in the Plan Editor provides a visualization of how information ought to flow in the situation that is the focus of the currently selected segment. The flow map is redrawn when the planner close a form in which changes have been made; it is not redrawn while the form is open and changes are being made.

figure.title: Maximized flow map for a segment

section.para: Tasks are the nodes (icons over text) in the graph. Information needs, capabilities, and information sharing flows (flows) are represented by the arrows.
Tasks and flows are drawn in red if they have known issues (either detected by Channels or by planners).

Green and red traffic lights represent the start and end of the event phase covered by the segment. Tasks that are triggered by the start of the segment are connected to the green traffic light icon. Tasks that cause an event are connected to a green traffic light representing the start of the event. Tasks that terminate the event phase are linked to the red traffic light.

Information flows (information shared), information needs (information needed for carrying out, triggering, or terminating a task), and information capabilities (shareable information produced by the execution of a task) are all shown as arrows. Single-headed arrows represent notifications. Double-headed arrows are request-replies, with the empty arrowhead pointing to the task that consumes the information request, and the solid arrowhead pointing to the task that consumes the answer (the requested information flows to it). Receipt-confirmation receipt flows are show with a a half-arrow at one end representing the confirmation (see legend below). On-failure-only flows are represented with a black (or red if issue) square at the where the arrow connects to the failing task.
section.db:para: Tasks are are deemed not to be realizable in the current environment are annotated with a small red "x" icon. A tasks may not be realizable, for example, because no agent can (yet) be assigned to it. Flows that can not be realized (no IS commitment found, for example) are displayed as dotted lines.
section.para: Small squares connected to tasks are used in displaying information needs and capabilities. They stand for to-be-determined tasks. An arrow from a task to a dot represents an information capability of the task (information produced by the task that can be shared for use in other, to-be-determined tasks). An arrow from a small square to a task represents an information need of the task (the task needs information possibly produced by other, to-be-determined tasks).

When risks and goals are shown in a flow map, they appear respectively as colored flags and stars connected to tasks (if they achieve a goal) and segment end icons (if goals are achieved by ending the segment's event phase).
Tasks within a blue-gray rectangle denote tasks from other segments that are connected by flows to tasks in the segment being viewed.
The flow map legend is shown by clicking on the "Help" icon in the flow map's display controls.

section.title: Flow map display controls
section.para:
The flow map display controls at the top left corner of a flow map give planners options as to how the flow map is displayed. The controls allow planners to:
Show/hide information needs and capabilities
Show/hide goals achieved by tasks
Show/hide tasks and flows not marked as operational
Maximize/un-maximize the flow map
Reduce the flow map to fit
Show the flow map legend

Flow maps can become quite large. A flow map can be reduced to fit within the available space by clicking on the "resize-to-fit" view control. Clicking on the icon once more brings the flow map back to its full size.

figure.title: Flow map displayed at full size

section.para: A flow map can be maximized to use all of the screen space allocated to the Plan Editor by clicking on the "maximize" view control. A maximized flow map can also be reduced to fit. A flow map is un-maximized either by clicking once more on the "maximize" view control or by selecting a task or a flow within the map.

figure.title: Maximized flow map resized to fit

section.para: A flow map, by default, does not display risks and gains (goals) and how they relate to tasks or the segment as a whole. To display risks and gains, the planner must click on the "show goals" control. Clicking again hides the goals.

figure.title: Flow map showing goals achieved by tasks

section.para: A flow map, also by default, does not display information needs and capabilities (tasks connected by arrows to square dots). To display information needs and capabilities the planner must click on the "show needs and capabilities" control. Clicking again hides them.

figure.title: Flow map showing information needs and capabilities

section.para: Channels determines if tasks and flow can be realized in the currently defined environment (i.e. with the organizations and their agents known to the plan.) A task can be realized if agents can be assigned to it on a 24/7 basis. A flow can be realized if it yields workable information sharing commitments (people can reach and understand one another.) Tasks that can not be realized as stamped with a small "x" icon. Flows that can't be realized are displayed as dotted line arrows. Planners can hide tasks and flows that can't be realized (in the current environment) from the flow map to highlight more strikingly what parts of a plan could work.

figure.title: Flow map showing tasks and flows, realizable or not
Flow map hiding tasks and flows that can't be realized

section.para: The planner can expand the height of the task, receives, and sends panels at the bottom, at the expense of the flow map, by pressing the "expand forms" view control. Clicking again un-expands the bottom panels.

figure.title: Task, sends and receives panels expanded

section.title: Collaboration tab panels
section.para: The collaboration tab panels on the right side of the Plan Editor allow a planner see who else is working on the plan and what changes they made recently. A planner can send messages to a single planner or to all users and can read received messages. The collaboration tab panels can be collapsed if more screen space for the flow map and task/flow forms is needed.

figure.title: Expanded collaboration tab panels in plan editor
How to expand collaboration tab panels when collapsed

section.title: Presence tab
section.para: The presence tab by default shows users currently logged in and who selected the current plan (and version) from their Home pages. The presence tab is automatically and regularly refreshed. A planner can ask to see all registered users whether or not they are logged in. A message can be addressed to a planner from the "more" menu.

figure.title: Presence tab showing only users logged into the plan
All users who can see this plan

section.title: Activities tab
section.para: The activities tab lists all the latest changes made to the plan in one place. Each change record contains the nature of the change, what plan element was changed, who did it, and when. If the plan element that was changed is still in the plan, then clicking on it takes the planner to it.

figure.title: All recent changes made to the plan

section.title: Messages tab
section.para: The messages tab enables planners (and only planners) to send personal messages to another user with access to the currently selected plan, or to broadcast messages to all planners or participants.
A planner can show or hide broadcasts (non-personal messages), and alternately look at messages received or sent.

Messages can be sent "internally," to be read only from within the messages tab, or they can be sent via email. Internal messages can be "resent" by email. Messages sent internally can also be deleted.

A message sent from the context of a plan element will include a reference to that element. The recipient of the message can click on that reference to be taken to the plan element, if the element still exists in the plan.

figure.title: Sending and receiving a message about a plan element (here a task)

section.para: Note that the messaging capabilities of Channels should be used only while planning and should not be used during emergencies.

section.title: Acquiring and releasing edit locks
section.para: More than one planner can concurrently work on a plan.
