When two planners attempt to modify the same definition of a task, flow, entity etc., Channels allows only one planner to modify the form's field by giving the other planner read-only access to the form. Access is on a first-come-first-serve basis.

When a planner opens an edit form on a plan element, Channels attempts to grab an edit lock on behalf of the planner for that plan element. If another planner already owns the lock, the form is shown to the first planner with the editable fields disabled.
A lock on a plan element owned by a planner is released when the planner collapses or closes its edit form, or logs out. Note that the flow map is refreshed only when an edited form is closed.

The name of the owner of a lock appears to other planners usually in the place of the "actions" menu for the locked plan element. A message can be sent to the owner of a lock by clicking on his/her name.

A planner waiting for edit locks is notified with a message in the segment bar when any of the locks is released. The planner is then instructed to refresh the editor in order to acquire the released locks and enable editing. Mousing over the refresh notice shows the reason for it. Note that a refresh notice will also appear when another planner has made a change to the plan.
A planner who owns one or more locks and is inactive long enough loses all acquired locks. The opened forms become read-only and other planners waiting on these locks are notified.

figure.title: Edit lock lost on time out

section.title: Autocomplete form fields
section.para: Naming matters a lot in Channels. Entities are referenced by their unique names and are created when first named. Using different names for what is essentially the same role, type of organization, etc. would become a source of confusion and would undermine the usefulness of an IS plan. Whether the names of tasks, flows, information needs, capabilities, and information elements are different or the same determines whether needs are satisfied or satisfiable.

To help planners converge toward a coherent vocabulary, Channels often will suggest alternative names already in use via a drop down menu when a planner is entering a name. Channels uses semantic proximity matching to suggest to a planner not only names that look the same but names that have similar meanings. The planner may then elect to use a name already used instead of a new one with similar meaning.

section.title: Attaching documents
section.para: Plan elements are documented and annotated by attaching files to them. These files can either be uploaded to the Channels server, or they can be linked to from Channels if they are reachable over the Internet or over an intranet in which Channels operates.

Documents can be attached, copied, or detached. Attachments are assigned a type. Certain types of attachment, for example, the picture type and the tags type impact the behavior of Channels (icons are generated and used, tags are added to the tag domain, etc.) Attachments can be named. The default name of an attachment is its URL.
Uploading an attachment takes the planner to the platform's file chooser. Linking to a document requires only entering a URL (the http:// prefix is implied if not given).
Channels will at some point delete uploaded documents that have been detached.

section.title: Floating panels
section.para: Many panels in Channels are of the "floating" sort. They can be moved, resized, brought to the front and closed.

The following are floating panels:
Plan definition panel
Segment definition panel
Entity profile panel (to edit agents, events, phases, organizations etc.)
Surveys panel (surveys about a plan element or the plan as a whole)
Task assignments panel
Sharing commitments panel
Task overrides panel
Elements of information panel
Failure impact analysis panel
Dissemination analysis panel
Assignments and commitments (visualization) panel
Requirements panel
Flow map legend panel
All surveys panel
Feedback management panel
There can only be one entity profile panel opened at a time, only one task assignments panel, etc. These various panels are covered below.

section.title: Tasks, receives and sends panels
section.para: The task, receives and sends panels at the bottom of the plan editor show summaries of the selected task (there is always a task that is selected) together with a list of summaries of its "receives" (the task's information needs and the information flows to it) and a list of its "sends" (the task's information capabilities and the information flows from it). A task or send/receive summary can be expanded into a form for editing the definition.

Clicking on the summary of a task, or selecting the "details" option in the task's "Show" menu, expands it by opening its edit form. To expand a "send" or "receive", a planner must first select it by clicking in its summary and then click the selected send/receive, or select "details" in the "Show" menu at the top of the list of sends/receives. Clicking on a send/receive in the flow map both selects it and expands it. Remember that when expanding a form, an edit lock is acquired if no one else has it. If someone else has it, the form is "read-only".

The form for a task or for a send/receive comes in two formats: a simple format (the default) and the advanced format. A planner can switch between the two. The simple form format shows fewer fields and they tend to be the ones most often used. Typically, a planner will use mostly the simple forms to "sketch" tasks and sends/receives, and only later use the advanced forms to add more details.
Channels automatically adapts the width of task and flow forms to provide ease of editing. Clicking on a summary closes the form.
Note that, with very few exceptions, any and all fields in any form in Channels can be left blank. Of course, leaving all fields in a form blank is of little value.

Each of the summaries is prefixed with a colored corner triangle. The color of the triangle indicates how important a task or a flow is. The color indicates the calculated impact of the task or the flow failing completely. Blue indicates a minor impact, yellow is major, orange is severe, and red is extreme. Gray triangles are used when failure impact does not apply (information needs and capabilities).
section.db:para: If a send/receive can not be realized in the current environment, its summary is prefixed by a red "x" icon. A task that can not be realized is indicated by a "cog" icon with the red "x" in it.

figure.title: Task, send and receive panels can be expanded, collapsed

section.title: Editing a task
section.para: A planner defines a task by naming it, categorizing it, tagging it. (Remember, just about every field in Channels is optional.) The planner further defines it by characterizing where it is to be executed, by whom, in what role within what jurisdiction, and on behalf of what organization. Any of the location, agent, jurisdiction, role, and organization entities that specify a task can be left unnamed so as to imply that more than one agent can be assigned to the task. The names of entities can be indicated to refer to actual entities (Morristown, NJ, John Doe, ACME, etc.) or to types of entities (a city, a certified technician, a corporation, etc.).
section.db:para: The location where the task is to be executed is either named, communicated, the assigned agent's jurisdiction, or the organization's jurisdiction.
section.para: The execution of a task can be set to be “as a team” to indicate that all assigned agents are to work together when carrying out the task. By default, assignees are each to execute the task independently.

A task is also described by how long it normally takes to complete, whether it repeats and how quickly, and whether it starts automatically with the segment (implying that the assigned agents would become aware on their own of the onset of the segment's event phase).
The purpose of a task can be stated as causing an event, terminating the event phase addressed by the segment, mitigating one or more risks, or achieving gains within the segment's scope.
section.db:para: The task can be said to be "ongoing" (it's always being executed), or it to be initiated with the start of the event phase in which it is defined (no communication required).
section.para: Reference and policy documents can be attached to the task either by URL or by uploading them. Finally, the task can be given a brief, informal set of instructions.

As for any plan element, a planner can add issues to those automatically detected about the task. Issues added by a planner can later be removed by any other planner. Issues detected by Channels cannot be removed, but can be waived.

The task's "Show" menu opens various views on the task, namely:
The details of the task as an edit form - a shortcut is to click on the task's summary
The assignments panel - all agents that are assigned to the task
Override panel - showing tasks that override or are overridden by this task (the menu item is not shown if there are no overrides)
The dissemination panel - analysis of element of information dissemination to and from the task
The task's surveys panel - surveys about the task that can be or have been launched
Entity profile panels - for all entities referenced in the definition of the task
The task actions menu becomes available when the task is expanded into its edit form (and the planner has acquired exclusive editing rights). Actions that do not apply are grayed out.

The actions available from the task actions menu are:
Undo the planner's last change to any plan element, if applicable
Redo the planner's last undone change, if applicable
Send a message about the task
Take a copy of the task
Cut (copy and delete) the task
Paste a copied attachment to the task's documentation, if applicable
Paste the copied task, if any - apply the copied task's definition to this task
Create a new task in this segment that is a copy of the current task
Connect this task with flows from other tasks that can satisfy (partially or completely) the info needs of this task
Disintermediate this task - directly connect tasks that use this one as a "middleman" for information sharing, bypassing this task

section.title: Editing a "send" or "receive"
section.para: The first step in defining either an information need, an information capability, or an information sharing flow is to name the information, identify its intent (command, alarm, announcement, report, or feedback), and define the elements of information, if any.
The mode of communication is given as either notification or by-request (push or pull).
Planners can specify if the information would be shared only in case to task failure ("sends" only).

If an information flow (information that is shared) is a notification, then it can be made a broadcast (information will be shared with all agents assigned to the target task) or a unicast (information will be shared with at least one agent assigned to the target task).
Keep in mind that an information flow that is a “send” to its source task is a ”receive” to its target task. One is looking at a single flow from either of its two ends.

An information flow can be created by first adding an information need to a task (if necessary), then adding an information capability of the same name in another (also if necessary), and then connecting the need to the capability or vice-versa by setting the “from” or “to” field to the other task. Another way to create an information flow is to start from an information need or capability of a task and then name the task at the other end of the flow. If a task of that name does not exist, a new one is created and connected.

When specifying or determining the source or target of a flow, a planner can restrict the sources and targets to be within the same umbrella organization, within the same (overall or specific) organization, or within the same location, or a supervisor, or self, or someone else. Adding a restriction on a sharing flow may filter out sharing commitments that would otherwise be implied by the flow (e.g., by dropping any sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries if sharing is restricted to within an organization).

A communication delay is set either to zero (communication is to happen without delay) or to some finite time interval. For an information need, the delay represents the timeliness requirement for being notified (maximum delay from time of availability), or for getting a response to a request (maximum time elapsed from the request). For an information capability, the delay represents how quickly the information could be produced and communicated. For an information flow, the delay represents a “quality of service” commitment.

The communication channels over which the information is to flow can be set for both an information need and for a notification information flow, but only when viewed from the notified task. The same is true for a requested information flow when viewed from the task that responds to a request. Alternate communication channels are listed in order of preference.

When editing a “send” or “receive,” a planner can set whether sharing would normally trigger or terminate a task. A notification could trigger or terminate the receiving task. It could also terminate the sending task, if sending the notification concludes the task that produced the information. A request could trigger the task that produces a reply.

Planners can attach documents to a “send” or “receive.” A document can be a reference, a mandating policy, a prohibiting policy, an unspecified policy (contains language that may impose both obligations and restrictions), or it can be an image provided as an illustration (for example, a screenshot). Note that attaching a prohibiting policy to an information flow does not prohibit the generation of information sharing commitments.

Instructions can be given as text in the definition of "sends" and viewed in the definitions of received information flows. Planners can express in "sends" whether a receipt confirmation is requested, whether the situation (event phase and context) is to be also communicated as part of a transmission, and , if applicable, whether an intermediate can be bypassed if unreachable.

figure.title: Edit form for an information need
Edit form for an information capability
Edit form for an information flow (here a "receive")

section.para: Information needed, shareable, or to-be shared can be decomposed into named elements. Each element of information sent or shareable can be described and assigned individual secrecy classifications as well as handling instructions. Planners can indicate whether and how a "sent" element of information is related to a received element of information (is the same one but renamed, is it an aggregation of many received elements?).

An element sent is implicitly the same as one received if both are identically named and both comprise identically named incoming and outgoing information. If an element sent is in effect the same as one received but they have different names or comprise information with a different name, then planners need to indicate that the element sent renames the element received. If an element sent is a compilation/summation of multiple elements received, planners can identify the received elements that are aggregated into a sent element. Doing so enables Channels to track the planned dissemination of information.

To reduce the drudgery of defining elements of information, the list can be auto-populated by clicking on the magic wand icon. Clicking on the classifications "link" icon forces all elements to have the same classification. Clicking again removes the constraint.

figure.title: Editing shared or shareable elements of information

section.para: The elements of information of an information need do not have secrecy classifications, descriptions, special handling instructions, or transformation attributes. They do however have time-sensitivity attributes to indicate which of the elements are subject to the timing requirements of the information need they define.
When a planner selects a send/receive, a "Show" menu appears at the top of the list of "sends" or "receives". If the planner then opens the form for the send/receive, an "Actions" menu also appears.

The "Show" menu of an information need allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information need
Edit the elements of information (only if the "send/receive" form is shown)

The "Actions" menu of an information need allows the planner to:
Undo the last change made by the planner to the plan (if possible)
Redo the last change undone by the planner ( if possible)
Take a copy of the information need
Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information need
Add a copied attachment to the information need's documentation, if applicable
Remove the information need

figure.title: Information need menus for collapsed and expanded edit forms

section.para:
The "Show" menu of an information capability allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information capability
Edit the elements of information (only if the "send/receive" form is shown)

The menu for an expanded information capability additionally allows the planner to:
Undo the last change made by the planner to the plan (if possible)
Redo the last change undone by the planner ( if possible)
Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information capability
Add a copied attachment to the information capability documentation, if applicable
Remove the information capability

figure.title: Information capability menus for collapsed and expanded edit forms

section.para:
The "Show" menu of an information flow allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information flow
Edit the information flow elements (if the edit form is shown)
View the information sharing commitments computed for this flow
View the failure impact analysis for this flow
View the information dissemination analysis for this flow

The "Actions" menu of an information flow additionally allows the planner to:
Undo the last change made by the planner to the plan (if possible)
Redo the last change undone by the planner ( if possible)
Take a copy of the flow
Add the information need (if flow is a receive) or capability (if flow is a send) implied by this flow (duplicate flow)
Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information flow
Add a copied attachment to the information flow documentation, if applicable
Remove the information flow
Break the flow into two flows by inserting an undefined, intermediate task in the flow
Break up the flow by removing it and adding the information capability of the source task in implied (if not already defined) plus, and by adding information need of the target task it implied (also if not already defined)

section.title: Access to a plan's views
section.para: The plan definition panel is opened by selecting the item “About Plan” in the top “Show” menu.
The "Show" menu of the plan definition panel gives access to other views on the plan, namely:

listitem.para: The requirements panel for defining and analyzing IS requirements
A list of all events referenced in the plan, with the ability to declare certain events as "incidents" (i.e., outside events not expected to be caused by planned tasks)
The list of all organizations within the scope of the IS plan, where a planner can indicate if an organization is expected to be assigned planned tasks
A list of all registered users and their identification with agents in the plan (participations)
The list of all secrecy classifications (also referenced in the plan), with the ability to add and edit secrecy classifications
An overall evaluation of the plan with issues metrics
A searchable list of all issues anywhere in the plan
A visualization and analysis of how all segments interrelate
An index of all named plan elements (tasks, flows, entities, etc.)
A tool for visualizing typologies implied by the entity definitions in the plan
A searchable list of all tags used in the plan with references to the plan elements tagged
A visual exploration tool of assignments and commitments (IS procedures) computed from the plan
A searchable who's who of all participating agents
A searchable list of all document attachments
A mechanism for voting to release the current development version of the plan into production

section.title: Plan details
section.para: Planners use the plan definition panel's details view...

listitem.para: to change the name of a plan
give it a description
define phases to be applied to events
localize the plan
set the default language of agents
attach documents to the plan (they will be linked from the Home page)attach documents to the plan (they will be linked from the Home page)
and add ad hoc issues about the plan as a whole

section.title: Requirements
section.para: The Requirements view is where planners manage an initially empty list of information sharing requirements (requirements on the information sharing commitments to be produced by the plan), and where they evaluate how well each requirement is satisfied by the pairs of organization to which it applies.

figure.title: Accessing requirements from top Show menu

section.db:para: In the "definitions" tab of the requirements view, planners can add, edit and remove IS requirements. Planners can name a requirement, describe it, attach documents to it, and add issues about it.

Planners define a requirement by specifying the information that is to be the object of IS commitments. This is done by specifying the "committers" and beneficiaries in these IS commitments, and by setting the minimum, maximum and safe counts of committing agents per source organization, of beneficiary agents per receiving organization, and of committing agents per beneficiary agent.

All fields in the definition of a requirement are optional, except for some numeric fields and those have default values. The information specification in a requirement definition consists of the name of the information, information tags and the names of elements of information. The information and element of information names match those uses in the definitions of flows (case and extra blanks are ignored). Element names can be added only if the information is named (they are meaningless otherwise).

Since requirement specifies IS commitments one organization toward another, a requirement will characterize more or less broadly the agents in the source organization who will commit to share the information specified above. The requirement will also characterize the agents in the receiving organization who are the beneficiaries of the commitments. The committing and beneficiary agents are characterized the same way agents are characterized in a task definition, namely by agent name/type, role, jurisdiction (place name or type) and organization (name or type). AN empty characterization matches all agents in all organizations.

Note that the values in the organization fields of both sources and receivers specifications are used during requirements analysis to determine the pairs of organizations to which the requirement can apply. If neither source organization and receiver organization are set, then the requirement will apply to all possible pairs of organizations. If for example, the plan has organizations A and B in scope, such a requirement will apply to source-receiving pairs A-B and B-A.

Planners can specify in a requirement the context in which the information to be shared is acquired (in Sources/When) and the context in which the information is needed (in Receivers/When) . This is done by naming the task by which it is acquired (case and extra blanks are ignored) , naming tags on the task and specifying the phase and/or event when the task is executed.

A requirement defines how many agents in a source organization are expected to commit to sharing the information as specified, and how many agents in a paired beneficiary organization are to receive it (always keep in mind that requirements apply to pairs of organizations). There is a minimum count (for weak satisfaction), which can be zero or greater, a safe count (for strong satisfaction), which must be the same as or greater than the minimum count, and a maximum count (that must not be exceeded for the requirement to be satisfied), which can be left undefined but otherwise must be the same as or greater than the safe count.

Finally a requirement can express how many alternate committing agents each beneficiary agents must have for the requirement to be satisfied. This is also defined in terms of a minimum, safe and maximum number.

Planners can visualize how well requirements are satisfied by participating organizations in committer-beneficiary relationships. A diagram shows all "required networking" relationships as arrows from source organizations to receiving organizations. Each arrow is labeled by the number of requirements that apply to the pair. An arrow is colored red if any one of the requirements it represents is not satisfied.
Under the diagram is a table containing all the applied requirements represented in the diagram. The content of the table can be sorted, filtered and paged.

A planner can also focus on the required "required networking" of a particular organization by clicking on it int the diagram, or the planner can focus on the required networking between a pair of organizations. The full digram is restored by clicking in the empty space near to an organization or an arrow.

A planner can see all the requirements applied to pairs of organizations, see the IS commitments that contribute toward the satisfaction of each applied requirement, and then drill down into each IS commitment to see the task and flow definitions from which the commitment was generated.
The planner can choose to focus the analysis of requirement satisfaction to before, during or after an event.

section.title: Events in scope
section.para: The All events view collects all events identified by name anywhere in the plan and thus implicitly in the scope of the plan. A planner uses this view to explicitly add events to the scope of the plan. To be explicitly added to a plan, an event must be marked as an incident. If an event is not marked as an incident and is no longer referenced anywhere in the plan, it is automatically removed from the plan.

A planner can mark an event as an incident if it is caused outside of the plan and not as an outcome of a planned task. The event is put in scope and remains in scope even if it not referenced anywhere else in the plan.
There is always at least one event defined in a plan. Unmarking as incident an event that is not defined and is not referenced anywhere in the plan removes it from the plan.
section.db:para: To see where an event is referenced in the plan, a planner clicks on the name of the event to open the profile panel for that event where references can be found.

section.title: Secrecy classifications
section.para: The Secrecy classification view is where planner can add, edit and view all defined secrecy classification systems. Once defined, a secrecy classification can be used to qualify elements of information (classification), transmission media (security), and agents (security clearances).
section.db:para: A classification system is simply a named and ordered list of named classifications.
section.para: Classifications can be reordered, references to a classification can be listed, unreferenced classifications can be removed, and new classification systems and classifications added.

section.title: Organizations in scope
section.para: The All organizations view collects all actual organizations implicitly in the scope of the place by virtue of them being referenced anywhere in the plan, for example, in the definitions of tasks. Planners can explicitly add actual organizations to the scope of the plan with expectations that they be assigned tasks. An issue is raised if an organization explicitly added to the scope of the IS plan and none of its agents are assigned a task.
section.db:para: Unless an organization is marked as being expected to have task assignments, that organization is automatically removed from scope as soon as it is no longer referenced by tasks or by other entities.
section.para: A network view of all inter-organization sharing commitments is available to explore the sharing commitments implicit in a plan that crosses organizational boundaries.

section.title: Segments map
section.para: In the All segments view, planners can look at a diagram showing how the segments in the plan inter-connect. Segments inter-connect when a task in one segment is connected by a flow to a task in another segment, or when a task initiates the phase of an event that is the context of another task.

The segments can be viewed grouped by phase or by event. Planners can browse all cross-segment sharing flows as well as all tasks in one segment that start or terminate (the event phase of) another segment (causations).

section.title: Visualizing assignments and commitments
section.para: The Assignments and commitments view is an essential tool for planners. It lets planners visualize and explore the assignments and commitments that are generated by a plan. If one thinks of an IS plan as an "IS commitment generator", then the assignments and commitments view is a means for planners to validate that the plan is working right.

Remember that task assignments and information sharing commitments are implicit in a plan and are computed by Channels by matching known agents with task assignee specifications, and by applying the sharing restrictions set on flows that connect tasks to agents. In other words, assignments and commitments (IS procedures) are the result of applying an environment (known agents employed by known organizations) to an informations sharing model (specifications of tasks and flows).
section.db:para: The assignments and commitments view produces a diagram of all task assignments linked by IS commitments, in essence a visual map of the IS procedures implicit in the plan. Planners should keep in mind that, even though the diagram looks very much like a flow map and correlates to them, it is not a flow map; the nodes are task assignments (not task definitions) and the arrows and IS commitments (not information flows).

figure.title: Plan panel - assignments and commitments diagram
figure.para: Planners should take the time to become familiar with this view and then use of it to validate the meaning of a plan defined by the IS procedures it produces.

section.para:
Because an IS procedures diagram can quickly become quite large and unwieldy, the view allows planner to:
Focus on the assignments and commitments of actual agents or organizations (as an aggregate of its agents), filtering out the rest
Look at the IS procedures generated from a single segment or from the entire plan
Aggregate, or not, the assignments and commitments shown by
type of organization
type of organization and role
organization (actual)
organization and role

figure.title: Plan panel - assignments and commitments - focusing

section.title: Agents in scope
section.para: The Who's who view collects all actual agents mentioned anywhere in the plan that are assigned roles by the organizations in scope. The view lists all agent "jobs".
Planners can search, filter, and sort the list and use it to access agent, role and organization profiles.

section.title: All issues
section.para: The All issues view collects all issues detected by Channels or entered by planners throughout the plan. Planners use it to sort, filter, and browse the plan's issues.
Planners can initiate surveys on the resolution of individual issues or they can access existing surveys.

section.title: All attachments
section.para: The Bibliography view collects all uploaded or linked attachments throughout the plan. Planners browse, filter, sort and access the attachments.

section.title: Plan index
section.para: The Index view collects into an index everything in the plan that has a name. Planners can find, filter, sort, and navigate to these named plan elements.

section.title: Plan typologies
section.para: Entities can be categorized by entity types (agents are categorized by agent types, role are categorized by other roles, etc.). The All types view shows planners the typologies implied by the categorizations of entities. Planners can choose a tree layout or a "web" layout as appropriate.
section.db:para: The typology view is an essential tool for planners. How entities are categorized (in terms of entity types) determines, for example, which agents match the assignment characterizations set in a task's definition. A small change in, say, the typology of roles can drastically alter who is assigned to the plan's tasks and thus greatly impact the IS commitments produced from the plan.

The typology view is the only way by which a planner can see at once the typologies that are otherwise implied by the categorization of a potentially large number of entities (the categorization of an entity is part of that entity's profile). Without this view, it would be very hard for a planner to catch "typology bugs" that invalidate an entire plan.

section.title: Plan tag index
section.para: The tags defined and used in a plan are consolidated in the All tags view where a planner can find what tags are used in a plan and what elements are tagged by a given tag.

section.title: Plan evaluation (issues metrics)
section.para: The Evaluation view gives a summary evaluation of the plan's fitness by providing metrics about validity, completeness, and robustness issues. The metrics are high level, aggregating issues based on robustness vs. completeness vs. validity, and based on severity level.
More detailed issue metrics can be found in the Issues Summary report reachable from the home page.

section.title: User participations in the plan
section.para: The Participations view lists all registered users and the identity of the agent, if any, that is associated with each user. The planner can make or change these associations as well as update the contact information a participant inherits from the associated agent. A user who is not associated with an agent does not have access to information sharing guidelines or information needs reports.
section.db:para: The IS Guideline report, accessible from the home page, provides an alternate mechanism by which planners can set user participation.

section.title: Plan versions
section.para: The Versions view is where planners vote to move the development version of the plan into production.

Note that only an administrator can actually move a development version into production from within the Administrator page. It is assumed that an administrator would first consult this view before deciding to move the current development version of the plan into production. A unanimous vote is not required since it is the administrator who, unilaterally but hopefully after consultation with planners, puts the development version of a plan into production.

section.title: Actions on the plan as a whole
section.para: The actions menu of the plan definition panel enables the planner to undo/redo past changes, send messages about the current plan version, and add issues about the plan as a whole.

section.title: Segment definition panel
section.para: Planners can edit the scope, name and description of a segment. A segment's definition panel is accessed by selecting “About plan segment” from the “Show” menu in the segment bar, or by clicking on the name of the segment also in the segment bar.

This opens the Details view in the segment definition panel. There, the segment can be renamed, and the phases and events of the scenario it covers can be changed. The event focused on in the scenario can be given the minimum rating (low, medium, high, or highest). As with any other kind of plan element, reference and policy documents can be attached to a segment, and ad hoc issues can be added.

The "Show" menu in the segment definition panel gives access to views other than the default Details view, namely:
Goals view - to view and edit the goals of the segment
Organizations view - to view the organizations involved in this segment and the sharing commitments between them
Map view - to locate segment tasks on a Google map
The task mover panel - to move tasks out of the segment to another
The segment's survey panel - to see all surveys that can or have been launched about the segment

The segment is further defined by identifying and describing a set of goals that relate to the event phase addressed by the segment. Goals can be risks to be mitigated or gains to be made. These goals are expected to be realized by tasks in the segment. A segment is expected to have at least one goal.

The Goals view of a segment lets planners define the goals of organizations that are in scope for this segment. Goals can be added and removed. The goal of an organization would be to mitigate a risk or to make a gain. A goal is defined in terms of:
A type picked from a taxonomy of risks or gains, an importance (minor, major, severe, or extreme for risks; low, medium, high, or very high for gains)
The identity of the organization (either an actual organization or a type of organization)
Whether the goal goes away when the event phase covered by the segment terminates
The tasks that mitigate a given risk or achieve a goal in scope can be listed, sorted and navigated to.
The Map view opens a window with a Google map showing all tasks in the segment that specify geo-locatable locations. The geomapping of elements is available whenever applicable throughout Channels.

figure.title: Google map of located tasks in a segment

section.para: The Actions menu of the segment definition panel enables the planner to undo/redo past changes, send messages about the segment, and add issues about the segment as a whole.

section.title: Entity profile panels
section.para: A new entity (an agent, role, organization, place, event, phase, or transmission medium) is automatically created when it is first referenced by name. Channels requires that all entities of a given kind be assigned unique names (John Smith, John Smith (1), John Smith (2), etc.).

The definitions of plan elements can reference both actual entities (ACME Corporation, Peter Sanchez, Morristown NJ) and types of entities (Corporation, Certified Emergency Technician, City). An entity is categorized by listing the names of entity types. An entity can only be categorized with entity types of its own kind (Warehouse A can be categorized as a building but not as a senior executive). The profiles of actual entities and entity types can be edited.
A profile panel for an entity, actual or type, can be opened from wherever the entity is referenced by name, be it in the specification of a task, in the definition of a segment, in an index, etc.

figure.title: Opening entity profiles from a task panel
Accessing entity profiles from the plan index or a reference index

section.para:
As a rule, entity profile panels have these views:
A Details view where entity attributes are edited
A Network view, where applicable, showing how the entity relates to other entities of the same kind
A Map view, where applicable, showing in a separate window where the entity is located
An Issues view where issues that relate to the entity are collected

An entity profile panel opens by default in the Details view. The Details view contains a form for editing the attributes of an entity. All entity profiles, whether they are actual or types, are defined by:

listitem.para: A unique name
A description (free text)
Tags
A categorization (a list of entity types of the same kind)
Document attachments

section.para:
In addition, an entity profile includes:
Some analytical content that relates to the entity
An index of all references to the entity, and matches with the entity, if the entity is a type
A list of all issues about the entity itself or that relate to the entity
A filterable collection of all other entities that relate to the entity
Each kind of entity has additional, specific attributes and these are reflected in the Details view for each kind of entity.
The Network view in the entity profile panel is available for agents, roles, and organizations. It shows how such entities have information sharing commitments with others of the same kind.
If the profiled entity is geo-locatable, a Map view shows where it is located in a different window. A Map view is available for organizations, events, and, of course, places.
An Issues view can show not only issues about the entity, but issues that relate to it. It is available for all kinds of entities.

The Actions menu in profile panels allows planners to:
Undo the planner's last change, if possible
Redo the last undone change, if possible
Send a message about the profiled entity
Add an attachment copied from another plan element, if any
Add an ad hoc issue to the profiled entity

section.title: Role profile panel
section.para: Roles are always entity types, so there's only one kind of profile panel for roles. The edit form in the Details view is a simple one because the profile of a role only has those attributes that are common to all entities.

figure.title: Role profile panel - Details view - analytical content expanded

section.para: The Network view shows how agents, aggregated in the profiled role, have sharing commitments with agents in other roles, also aggregated. The role-playing agents and their sharing commitments aggregated in the visualization are separated out in the sortable, filterable, page-able table underneath the diagram.
The Issues view collects issues about or related to the role and presents them in a filterable, sortable, page-able table. Planners can control which issues are displayed.

section.title: Organization profile panel
section.para: A planner profiling an actual organization can define its mission and give its location, contact information, parent organization, and any transmission media not implemented by the organization.

A planner can declare that it would be an issue should the profiled organizations have a sharing commitment with one another that is not covered by an agreement. A planner can also declare that it would be an issue should there be a role assigned by the organization in the plan for which there is no known agent.

A planner can add agents to an organization's membership/employment roster by naming the agent (required), the agent's role (required), jurisdiction (optional), title (optional), and supervisor agent (optional). Alternately, the planner can confirm memberships that are already implied by task specifications (a task definition can identify an agent by name in a role within a jurisdiction for an organization).

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - jobs

section.para: Jobs can also be added to an organization by transferring them, or copying them, from another organization.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - transferring jobs

section.para: Organizations with parent organizations form hierarchical structures that can be visualized as org charts.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - org chart

section.para: Inter-organizational sharing commitments are commitments between agents acting on behalf of different organizations. A sharing agreement may or may not exist for a sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries. It is an issue if an inter-organizational sharing commitment is unconfirmed when it is required by the committing organization. When viewing an organization, a planner can see the sharing commitments the organization makes with other organizations and confirm whether each commitment is covered or not by an agreement. A planner can attach documents of type MOU (Memorandum of Understanding) to confirmed sharing agreements. A sharing agreement not documented by a Memorandum of Understanding is an issue.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - sharing agreements

section.para: The task assignments and sharing commitments of the organization can be expanded at the bottom of the view. This is followed by an index of plan elements referencing the organization, and by issues about the organization itself, if any.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - expanded analytical content

section.para: The Details view of an organization type is much simpler than that of an actual organization.

figure.title: Organization type profile panel - Details view

section.para: In addition to the Details view, profile panels for organizations also provide a Network view, Map view (not shown), and Issues view.

figure.title: Organization type profile panel - Network view
Organization type profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Agent profile
section.para: The profile attributes specific to an actual agent are:

listitem.para: Whether or not the agent is an archetype or a placeholder or neither
Whether the agent is a system or a person
The agent's contact information (transmission media with addresses/endpoints where applicable)
The agent's availability
The agent's security clearances (as secrecy classification levels)
Languages spoken and understood by the agent, if different from the default language set for the plan

section.para: In addition to a profile attributes edit form, the Details view of an agent lists the roles played by the agent, the agent's task assignments and sharing commitments (if expanded), all references to the agent (indexed), and all issues detected or reported specifically about the agent.
An agent type has a simpler profile than an actual agent with only typical availability as an agent-specific entity attribute.

figure.title: Agent type profile panel - Details view

section.para: The agent profile panel includes Network, Map, and Issues views.

figure.title: Agent type profile panel - Network view
Agent type profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Place profile panel
section.para: When profiling an actual place, a planner can identify what other place, if any, contains it. A planner can also give the place a street address, postal code, and a geoname (the name of a town, state, mountain, lake etc.). If the geoname is ambiguous, more specific geonames are offered for confirmation.
When profiling a type of place, a planner can specify that actual places of this type must:

listitem.para: Be inside
the plan's locale
the location of an event in the plan's scope
or another actual or type of place
Contain
the plan's locale
the location of an event in the plan's scope
or another actual or type of place

figure.title: Place type profile panel - Details view

section.para: There is of course a Map view for actual place entities, and an Issues view for both actual places and place types.

section.title: Transmission medium profile panel
section.para: When editing a transmission medium, a planner can set the transmission mode to either unicast (one -to-one), multicast (one-to-many), or broadcast (one-to-any), unless the mode of this medium is already implied by that of another medium categorizing it.

The address pattern is a “regular expression” that constrains the form an “address” can take for this medium (see http://www.regular- expressions.info/ for a tutorial on regular expressions). An empty pattern imposes no constraint on the value of an address/endpoint.

A planner can identify what media this a transmission medium can interface with (delegates to) as it carries out transmissions from sender to receiver. For example, a notification system would interface with phone, email, pager, etc.

Finally, a planner can describe the security of the transmission medium in terms of secrecy classifications. Qualifying a medium as “US Gov/Top Secret” means that Top Secret information can be transmitted securely over this medium.
Keep in mind that all transmission media are types; there is no such thing in ISP as an "actual" transmission medium.

figure.title: Transmission medium profile panel - Details view

section.para: The profile panel for transmission media have an Issues view.

figure.title: Transmission medium profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Event profile panel
section.para: An event in ISP is always an entity type (all events in ISP are anticipated, none are actual). A planner can set the location (actual or type) where actual events of this type would occur. A planner can also indicate whether or not this type of event can terminate on its own, that is, without the intervention of agents.
The event profile panel has a Map and Issues views.

section.title: Phase profile panel
section.para: Planners can add any number of phases to the scope of a plan. In addition to setting generic entity attributes (name, description, classification), a planner indicates whether a phase is before an event (pre-event), during an event (co-event), or after an event (post-event).
The phase profile panel also has an Issues view to show all issues that relate to a profiled phase.

section.title: Survey launch panel
section.para: The survey launch panel is opened in the context of a plan element or in the context of the plan as a whole (from within the plane edit panel).
From this panel, surveys can be launched about the plan element, or the plan as a whole, if planners have defined a questionnaire about this kind of plan element, or about the plan.
section.db:para: The surveys panel allows the planner to see a list of all surveys that have been launched about the plan element or can be launched. A planner can launched a survey or access a launched survey. Lunching a survey creates a survey but does not yet invites participants to it. Launching or viewing a survey opens the "All surveys" panel where all the surveys launched in the plan are managed.

section.title: Task assignments and sharing commitments panels
Task assignments
section.para: Recall that a task can identity one assignee explicitly as an actual agent, but that tasks assignees are usually specified in terms of types of agents, roles, jurisdictions (actual or types of places), and organizations (types or actual). A task thus defined could be assigned to more than one agent. Channels looks up all agents known to a plan to determine which ones are to be assigned to the task.
A planner can look up the list of known agents that are implicitly or explicitly assigned to the task (the task assignments).

section.title: Information sharing commitments
section.para: Agents are implicitly bound by sharing commitments when they are assigned to tasks that are sources of shared information, subject to sharing restrictions. All agents assigned to the "source" task have sharing commitments with all agents assigned to the "recipient" task, except:

listitem.para: If the sharing flow is prohibited
If a restriction does not apply - For example, the source and beneficiary must be in the same organization or location, or the beneficiary must be the source's supervisor, etc.

section.para: A planner can look up the list of sharing commitments inferred by an information flow.

figure.title: Accessing information sharing commitments for a flow
Information sharing commitments for a flow

section.title: Task overrides panel
section.para: A task can be defined in such a way as to be a more specific case of another task, in effect overriding it. An overridden task can not be assigned any of the agents assigned to the overriding task. This allows planners to model exceptions and special cases in an IS plan.
When a task is overridden or overrides another, planners can bring up an overrides panel for that task.

figure.title: Access to the task overrides panel
Task overrides panel showing an overridden task
Task overrides panel showing an overriding task

section.title: Failure impact analysis panel
section.para: Planners can visualize what might happen should an agent fail completely at an assigned task or should an agent break a commitment to share information. The consequences could be a number of downstream tasks failing, leading to gains unachieved or risks unmitigated.

For the sake of analysis, it is assumed that a failure is always complete; a failed task does not produce any information that may be required by others, and a failed information flow does not transfer any information whatsoever.
A failure can cause a cascade of task failures if tasks directly or indirectly depend critically on, or are triggered by, information that fails to be produced or to be shared.

Not all sharing failures matter. If an information flow is not critical to a task or does not trigger it, then its failure does not propagate to other tasks. Furthermore, if the target of a flow can get the same information via another, non-failing flow, then the failure of the flow may not matter. Finally, if information produced by an agent is necessarily consumed by the same agent then, clearly, failure to share is meaningless.

Failure analysis only concerns itself with the failure of useful tasks. A useful task is one that achieves goals or one that produces information that triggers, terminates or is critical to another task that is itself useful. (Useless tasks are flagged as issues.)
Note that a task will terminate a risk if it causes a segment to end and if the risk is said to terminate with the segment.

A planner does “what-if” failure analysis by selecting a task or an information flow (“send” or “receive”) and then looking at the consequences should it fail. The planner can take a pessimistic outlook and assume that all redundant information flows would also fail, no matter what.

The result of the analysis is a cascade of failures visualized as a directed graph of information flows, tasks, gains, and risks. Risks that would otherwise be mitigated or terminated by failed tasks are shown as color-coded flags. Red is for extreme risks, orange is for severe risks, yellow for major risks, and blue for minor risks. Risks that would normally be mitigated by successful tasks are shown connected to these tasks. Risks that would be terminated, should a segment end, are shown connected to red stop lights. Each stop light is itself connected to a failed task that would normally end the segment.
Missed gains are shown as stars and are similarly color-coded by importance, with red for very high, orange for high, yellow for medium, and blue for low.

In addition to the visual map, a tabular list of failed, goal-achieving tasks (the failures that matter) is compiled and presented. The table is paginated and the columns (failing task, segment, impact, goal, magnitude of the loss, and organization impacted) can be sorted.

figure.title: Accessing the failure impact analysis on a task
Failure impacts of a failed task

section.para: Failure analysis crosses segment boundaries. A failed task in one segment can cause tasks to fail in other segments. Tasks, flows, and goals in segments other than the selected segment are put in blue-gray boxes.
The impacts of the failure of a specific flow can also be shown in a panel.

figure.title: Accessing the failure impact analysis on a flow
Failure impacts of a failed flow

section.title: Information dissemination analysis panel
section.para: If planners systematically indicate how elements of information flowing out of a task relate to elements of information flowing into a task, Channels becomes able to track the planned dissemination of individual elements of information. Dissemination tracking can be done forward (where does an element of information go?) and backward (where does an element of information come from?).

A dissemination panel can be opened from a task, offering a choice of all elements received or sent by the task, or it can be opened from a flow, restricting the choice to the elements shared via the flow.

Dissemination tracking from a task gives the option of looking at the sources as well as at the targets of individual elements of information. A dissemination panel opened on a "receive" flow only tracks sources, and a dissemination panel opened on a "send" flow only tracks targets.

figure.title: Access to dissemination panel from a task

section.para: Dissemination tracking is visualized as element flows. A table shows all source or target tasks, together with the transformations on the element from a source, or the cumulated transformations when reaching a target. The timeliness of the disseminations are indicated in the table. Untimely disseminations are indicated in red.

figure.title: Dissemination of an element from sources
Dissemination of an element to targets

section.title: All surveys panel
section.para: The "All surveys panel" allow planners to compose and manage questionnaires and to manage the surveys using these questionnaires that have been launched.
section.db:para: A survey is a questionnaire applied to a plan element (or the plan itself) and to which users are invited to participate.
A questionnaire is composed of statements and questions.

The following kinds of questions are supported:
Yes/no
Multiple choice
Short text - short answer requested
Essay - long answer requested
Document - document URLs requested
section.para:
Questions can be marked as
required vs optional - all required questions must be answered for the survey to be completed
allowing more than one answer
open ended - adds an opportunity for the participant to freely comment the answer(s)
section.db:para: Note that participants can change, remove, add answers at any time while the survey is ongoing. A survey should be understood as an open invitation to answer a number of questions with the ability to revise these answers even after they have been submitted.

section.title: Managing surveys
section.db:para: The "Surveys" tab lists the launched surveys. The list can be filtered on whether a survey is ongoing, what kind of plan element a survey is about, whether there have been responses to it.
Opening a survey gives access to survey controls, to a Participation tab to invite or nag survey participants, and to a Results tab to see the current results of the survey.

The survey controls allow planners to
preview the survey,
mark whether participants can forward the survey to whoever they chose,
retire the survey - making the survey unavailable to participants.
Under the Participation tab, planners can see all current and potential participants in the survey (the list can be filtered).

A planner then selects users to
invite them to the survey, possibly giving them a deadline to complete,
nag survey participants who are past their deadlines.

A survey preview shows how the survey will appear to participants. The preview behaves like the a real participant survey except that the buttons for submitting answers, declining or forwarding the survey are missing.
section.para: Under the result tab, planners can see how many participants have answered so far and see all the answers given so far to each question.
section.db:para: The answers are aggregated (most numerous on top) with the names of the participants who gave each particular answer.

section.title: Managing questionnaires
section.para: A questionnaire can be active or inactive. Inactive questionnaires can not be used in surveys and surveys launched based on since deactivated questionnaires are retired (re-activating the questionnaire un-retires them).

Individual questions in a questionnaire can also be deactivated in order for them to be edited. Only activated questions are shown in surveys. Only deactivated questions that have not been answered yet in any survey based on the questionnaire can be deleted.
The Questionnaires tab of the "All surveys" panel shows a list of questionnaires either composed by planners or automatically generated from issues (issue remediation surveys).

Planners can filter the list of questionnaires on whether a questionnaire
is active or not,
is about issue remediation or not,
is used by surveys.
section.db:para: A planner must open a questionnaire in order to edit it.
section.para:
Editing a questionnaire consists in
naming it,
indicating the kind of plan element the questionnaire is about (or if it is about the plan as a whole),
adding, removing, ordering and editing questions.
Editing a question consists in
Writing the text of the question
Selecting the type of answer - yes/no, short text etc.
Marking, or not, the question as required, open ended, allowing alternates
Activating it when done
A statement is dealt with as a special kind of question, one allowing no answer.
section.db:para:
The text of a question can contain template elements denoted by ${<something>}. The template element ${name} in a questionnaire about an event would be replaced in surveys by the name of the event. The consistently supported template elements are
${name} - the plan element's name
${description} - the descriptive text in the definition of the plan element
${id} - the internal id of the plan element
${user} - the full name of the survey participant
${planner} - the full name of the planner who launched the survey
section.para: Planners can delete a questionnaire but only if it is inactive and has not yet been used for any survey.

section.title: All Feedback panel
section.para:
The All Feedback panel lists all feedback received from users. The feedback can be filtered on
whether it was marked urgent by the user who sent it
whether it was marked resolved or not by the user
what topic the feedback is about
whether a planner has replied to it
whether it contains some given text fragment
The feedback is opened to respond to it and to see the thread of past responses and replies.
section.db:para: A reply can be sent internally to Channels or sent also via email.

section.title: All issues panel
section.para: The All issues panel collects all the issues detected by Channels and reported by planners into a table that can be filtered, sorted and paged.
section.db:para: The plan element on which the issue has been detected (or reported) can easily be navigated to from the panel.
Planners can launch or access issue remediation surveys from the panel.

section.title: Issues Summary Page
section.para: Channels summarizes all outstanding issues detected in and manually added to a plan in a page accessible from the Home page. The issues summary page provides metrics about the severities of the three overall types of issues (robustness, completeness, and validity), and about each kind of issue found in the plan. (Channels detects more than 90 different kinds of issues.)

section.title: IS Guidelines Page
section.para: Planners access a participants list page from the Home page and use it to access the IS guideline pages of any participant or any agent. (A participant is a user associated with an agent in the plan.)
Channels produces, on demand, personalized information sharing guidelines in report format for each participant.
A participant accesses his/her IS guidelines directly from the Home page only sees the list of the agents he/she is associated with.

The IS guidelines report organizes a participant's IS procedures generated from the plan by situations (relevant event phases, possibly in the context of past or present events) and connects the IS procedures with related contact information. The IS guidelines are presented in a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.

section.title: Information needs report
section.para: Channels produces, on demand, a report on the information needs of each participant.

Similarly to the IS Guidelines, a planner can see a list of information needs report for all participants or agents .A participant sees a list of information needs reports for the agents it is associated with.

figure.title: Accessing the information needs report of participants

section.para: The report lists the information needed by an agent to execute his/her assigned tasks in an IS plan. The information needs are organized by the tasks that require the information, and the tasks are themselves organized by the situations (relevant event phases, possibly in the context of past or present events) in which they are executed.

The degree to which information needs are satisfied (fully, somewhat or not at all) is indicated. The analysis is done at the level of individual elements of information. The information needs report is a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.

section.title: The Surveys Page
section.para: The Surveys page is where a user can find lists all the surveys he/she is participating in. The surveys are grouped as "todo", "done" and "declined". Each list is given a tab and can be sorted and paged (if the list is long).
section.db:para: Opening a survey shows the questions, the answers so far and buttons to forward a survey (if allowed by planners), decline it, cancel answers entered since last opening it, and submit new answers.

When answering a question, the survey participant can elect to make the answer visible to other participants or not. Answers to a question can be made available anonymously. The participant can see all visible answers from other participants from within the survey.
When declining a survey, a user is aked to provide a reason for declining. A declined survey can later be "un-declined".

section.title: The Feedback Page
section.para: The Feedback page enables the user to see all feedback he/she has sent to planners, and see their replies and any ensuing conversations.
section.db:para:
The list of feedback can be filtered on whether
it was marked urgent,
the problem, question or suggestion sent to planners has been resolved or not,
it is about a particular topic
there are replies
the feedback contains a text fragment

A user can open a feedback to
see it and all ensuing replies
mark it resolved (or un-resolved)

section.title: Getting Help and Sending Feedback
section.para: A planner accesses the Channels documentation by pressing on the Help button.
Feedback buttons appear in the Home page, in the Help page, in IS guidelines, and in the information needs report. Clicking on a feedback button opens a feedback panel.

section.title: Logging Out of Channels
section.para: A planner signs out to terminate a Channels session. Sign out buttons are available from the Home page as well as other pages.
Any edit locks still held by a planner are automatically released. The user is then presented with a login page.

section.title: Overview
section.para: Channels enables information sharing planners to apply the ISP Method, an incremental and nonlinear process for building information sharing plans from which useful analytics and robust information sharing procedures can be generated.

IS analytics enable planners to better understand the consequences and weaknesses of a plan while IS procedures enable participating organizations to more reliably fulfill their missions through information sharing, before, during, and/or after one or more events of significance.

The ISP Method defines:
The conceptual building blocks of a plan (see previous chapter)
The activities by which a plan is built, with prerequisites, steps, and outcomes
Strategies for moving a plan to completion
Issues that may keep a plan from being deemed valid, complete, and robust

section.title: ISP Method and ISP Process
section.para: The ISP Method is encompassed by the ISP Process. The ISP Process includes the ISP Method and adds best practices for the successful promotion, definition, initiation, implementation, and review of information sharing planning projects. The ISP Process, other than its significance to the ISP Method, is outside the scope of this document.

figure.title: Where the ISP Method fits within the ISP Process

section.para: The ISP Method is defined in terms of the ISP concepts covered earlier and of ISP Method activities (activities for short). These activities should not be confused with ISP Process best practices. For example, a ISP best practice might help planners decide what the scope an IS plan should be, whereas a plan scoping activity would indicate any prerequisite activities, prescribe how to capture the scope of a plan (once decided upon), and indicate what further activities could follow up changes to the scope.

section.title: Overview of the ISP Method activities
section.para: An IS plan is built by information sharing planners (planners) who carry out activities defined in the ISP Method in order to move the plan toward completion and also increase its value.
Activities alter the scope of an IS plan, bring the plan closer to completion, or improve the quality and value of the IS procedures generated from the plan.

Activities are organized into four groups:
Scoping an IS plan sets what an IS plan is about, but these activities can also be reapplied at any time, whenever the scope needs to change.
Specifying IS procedures by defining tasks and information flows from which the procedures are computed
Profiling referenced entities include types of events, roles, phases and transmission media, or actual or types of organizations, places, and agents
Improving the IS plan by making it more manageable, robust, complete, and reusable

There is no fixed, prescribed order to the execution of ISP Method activities. Scope can be modified at any time while an IS plan is being built. Tasks and information flows can also be added, removed, or modified at any point in time. Entities can be profiled as soon they are mentioned by name and they can be named at any time. An IS Plan can and should be improved early and often in order to keep it as manageable and as valuable as possible.

section.title: Issues
section.para: The ISP Method defines a relatively large number (100+) of issues that can be detected in an IS plan. They are categorized as:

listitem.para: Validity issues - something is incorrectly specified or defined
Completeness issues - something is apparently missing
Robustness issues - something makes the plan inherently failure-prone

figure.title: Summary of issues found in an IS plan

section.para: An issue can be about the IS plan as a whole, or about a segment, a task, a flow, an entity, or any other kind of plan element.

An issue can be assigned a severity of minor, major, severe, or extreme. The severity of an issue is either preset according to the kind of issue (for example, an information flow without elements of information is always a major issue), or computed by determining the most severe risk mitigation or gain capture that could be foiled by a cascade of failures caused by the issue.
An issue comes with one or more alternate options for its remediation. A planner can elect to launch a survey to gather opinions on how to remediate an issue.
All types of issues defined in the ISP Method can be detected by Channels. Some issue detections are “best guesses” and can be waived by planners if they are deemed to be false positives.

figure.title: Issues detected on a flow that can be waived

section.para: Planners can report ad hoc issues that are not in the list of 90+ predefined kinds of ISP issues Issues reported by planners will typically be domain-specific (all of the ISP issue types are domain-agnostic).

figure.title: Ad hoc issue reported by a planner about a task, with remediation options

section.para: A complete list of detectable ISP issues can be found in the Appendix.

section.title: Moving an IS plan to completion
Defining complete
section.para: When is an IS plan complete? There is really no satisfactory answer to this question. Because one could always increase the scope of a plan, a more useful question would be: Given its current scope, is there something clearly missing from a plan? If the answer is no, then the plan can be deemed “complete.”

Knowing whether the scope of an IS plan is properly set requires knowing the domains of human endeavor involved and being able to identify the organizations that ought to participate in the plan. Absent this knowledge, software can only examine an IS plan to detect what is inherently missing from it.

Nothing is inherently missing from a plan if:
All information sharing requirements are strongly satisfied.
Each phase of each event in scope is addressed by at least one segment of the plan.
An event is not self-terminating; each segment addressing a co-event phase for that event has at least one task that terminates the segment.
Each segment has at least one defined goal.
Each goal listed in a segment is achieved by at least one task within that segment.
Each participating organization and agent within the scope of the plan is assigned at least one task.
Each task is assigned to at least one agent.
Each information sharing flow generates at least one information sharing commitment.
Each task is useful in that it directly achieves a goal, or directly or indirectly enables a task that does.
Each referenced role in an organization is assigned to at least one member agent (if required).
Each inter-organizational information sharing commitment is covered by a sharing agreement documented by a Memorandum of Understanding (if required).
The scope of an IS plan can be changed even after it is deemed complete. Tasks, flows, and entities that do not contribute to completing a plan are considered redundant. Redundant tasks, flows, or entities should be removed from a plan. If the scope of a plan is reduced, some elements of a plan may become redundant as a result.

section.title: Completion strategies
section.para: The ISP Method proposes three distinct strategies for driving an IS plan toward completion:

listitem.para: Goal-driven strategy - Add goal-achieving tasks and work backward to satisfy their information needs.
Effect-driven strategy - Add tasks that execute at the onset of event phases and work forward by connecting tasks with outgoing flows.
Issue-driven strategy - Resolve or waive outstanding issues until none remains.

section.para: Planners usually use of all three strategies opportunistically when building an IS plan.

section.title: Goal-driven strategy
section.para: Planners look at each organizational goal attached to a phase of an anticipated event, add tasks that achieve it, and add the information needs of each of these tasks. They then add tasks that produce the needed information and connect the tasks with information flows. This process continues until all goals are addressed by tasks, and all task information needs are satisfied.
Step 1 - Select a goal within a segment

figure.title: A risk mitigation goal in a segment

section.para: Step 2 - Add a task that achieves the goal

figure.title: Adding a task that mitigates the risk

section.para: Step 3 - Specify the information needs of the task

figure.title: Defining the information needs of the risk-mitigating task

section.para: Step 4 - Add a flow-connected task to satisfy a need

figure.title: A task and flow are added to satisfy an information need

section.para: Systematic use of a goal-driven strategy guarantees that all tasks and flows, and consequently the IS procedures generated from them, are within the scope of the IS plan, because all tasks and flows contribute directly or indirectly to addressing identified goals. However, this strategy alone does not guarantee that tasks triggered by the start of event phases will be included. In other words, this "working from the end" strategy does not guarantee that it will reach all starting points.

section.title: Effect-driven strategy
section.para: Planners start with the onset of an event phase, add tasks that are either directly started by it or are ongoing at the onset. They then add the information flows from these tasks to other tasks that are triggered or terminated by the shared information. Planners indicate whether tasks initiate or terminate events. This process continues until no task gets triggered or terminated by information produced by specified tasks, and all event phases are covered.
Step 1 - Select an event phase and a segment focusing on it

figure.title: Segment created to cover an event phase

section.para: Step 2 - Add a task that is ongoing at the onset of the event phase or starts with it

figure.title: Task added that starts with the event phase

section.para: Step 3- Add a flow from task to a task it triggers or terminates

figure.title: Task added triggered by flow from started task

section.para: Systematic use of an effect-driven strategy is akin to telling a story from beginning to end, and thus may feel more natural to many planners. However some tasks and flows added using this strategy might not necessarily contribute directly or indirectly to achieving identified goals. In other words, a "starting from the beginning" strategy does not guarantee that it will reach all required end points.

section.title: Issue-driven strategy
section.para: When using an issue-driven strategy, planners scan the list of outstanding issues and determine which ones to either waive or resolve. Issues of validity ought to be dealt with first, followed by issues of completeness and then issues of robustness. Usually, everything else being equal, issues of higher severity should be given higher priority for remediation.

A planner selects a high-priority issue and either waives it (if applicable) or applies one of the recommended remediations, possibly after having queried other planners and/or participants. The process is repeated until no unwaived issue remains.

section.para: Step 2- Select issue
