The task missing with issue is navigated to

section.para: Step 3- Choose remediation, possibly by surveying other planners

figure.title: A survey can be launched about remediating the issue

section.para: Step 4- Apply remediation and solve issue

figure.title: The issue is resolved by connecting the task with an "on failure" flow

section.para: A plan with no outstanding, “unwaived” issues means that Channels and the planners considers the plan to be valid, complete, and robust. Because Channels has no domain knowledge (for example, it knows nothing about public health or mergers and acquisitions, etc.), domain-dependent issues will not be detected by Channels. Planners must use their own domain knowledge to determine if the IS plan has issues that lie outside the range of automatically detected issues.

section.title: About activities
section.para: An ISP Method activity is carried out by an IS planner either to correct a mistake in the definition of an IS plan, bring the plan closer to completion, or make it more robust.

An activity is composed of a number of steps, all of which may be optional, often to be carried out in no particular order. Most activities can be undone (for example, a task added to the IS plan can be later removed). Prerequisites for an activity, if there are any, are usually few and commonsense. For example, a task in a segment cannot be specified unless the segment is already defined.
Note that for each "Add ..." activity there is usually an implied and related "Remove ..." and "Modify ..." activity. For example, "Add task" implies "Remove task" and "Modify task".
Prior to applying any activity, it is assumed that:

listitem.para: An IS plan has been created and given a unique identifier (the identifier is not the name of the plan; it is universally unique and cannot be changed once the plan has been created)
Users have been authorized as planners
A default segment is created for a default phase of a default incident event (Channels does it automatically)

section.para: As stated earlier, activities fall under scoping a plan, specifying information sharing procedures, profiling entities, or improving a plan.

section.para: Adding a requirement makes explicit the kinds of IS commitments the IS plan is meant to produce between organizations. An issue is raised if a pair of organizations does not satisfy a requirement that applies to it.

section.title: Localizing the IS plan
section.para: Localizing an IS plan sets the locale or type of locale where the plan applies. This allows other places to be defined relative to the plan's locale, thus making easy to "move the plan" to a different locale (for example, from Philadelphia, PA to New York, NY). Localizing a plan is optional.

section.para: A plan's locale need not be set. If it is set, then place types within the plan can be defined to be within or containing the plan's locale (whatever it may be). Of course, a place identified as the plan's locale can not be defined relative to the plan's locale, either directly or indirectly through the definition of its place categories, containing places, or contained places. (See "Profiling a place").

section.para: The scope of an IS plan is largely set by identifying the types of anticipated events that are of concern. An event is considered an "incident" if it is unplanned (no task within the plan is expected to cause it). An IS plan always has at least one incident event within its scope. When an IS plan is created, an "unnamed" event is put in its list of incidents.

If planners want to also plan for the "before" or "after" of events, they need to add them to the scope of the plan by naming them in the Details view of the plan definition panel. section.title: Identifying a participating organization
section.para: An actual organization (as opposed to a type of organization) is implicitly added to the scope of an IS plan any time it is referenced by name in the definition of a task or of some other plan element. A planner can also make an actual organization part of the scope of a plan by adding it directly to the list of all organizations in the scope of the plan.

section.para: Organizations added to the scope of the plan by any method other than by directly adding them to the list of participating organizations will be removed from the scope if they are no longer referenced within the plan. By adding an organization to the list, it remains in the scope of the plan even if the organization is not referenced by name in any task definition (or in another organization's profile). An organization already referenced in the plan can be added durably to the scope by "adding expectations" that it is being assigned tasks. A planner can later remove such expectations.

section.title: Identifying a participating agent
section.para: The scope of an IS plan includes not only participating organizations but also participating agents, that is, agents as role-playing members of organizations that can be assigned to tasks. Agents "employed by organizations" are added to the scope implicitly from the definitions of tasks, or explicitly by defining the "jobs" of participating organizations that are relevant to the plan.

Since it is a best practice not to directly identify the assignees of tasks but rather to specify them via their roles in types of organizations, the preferred approach for identifying participating agents is to list them with their jobs in the profiles of participating organizations.

An agent is further identified by associating one or more users to it. The meaning of associating a user to an actual agent depends on whether the agent is designated as an archetype, a placeholder, or (the default) a normal agent.

An archetype agent captures the notion of a group of anonymous and indistinguishable agents (same contact info, same roles in the same organizations). An "ACME Call Center Agent" would be an archetype playing the role of "Call Center Agent" for the organization "ACME" and with some 1-800 number as its communication channel. Any number of Channels users can be associated with an archetype. These users all receive the IS guidelines of their associated archetype.

A placeholder agent is an agent whose identity is to be given via their associations with users. A placeholder agent can be given default contact information that the associated user(s) can override and add to. A placeholder agent can be restricted to only one associated user or can be open to associations with many users. A user associated with a placeholder agent gets the IS guidelines of that agent, with the user's contact info substitutions/additions.

The default kind of actual agent directly identifies the person or system and provides contact information as part of the profile. Only one user can be associated by planners with a normal, actual agent. The full name of the user and of the agent are expected to match (an issue is raised if not). The associated user gets the agent's IS guidelines. It is an ISP best practice to define agents, as much as possible, either as archetypes or as placeholders.

section.title: Adding a plan segment
section.para: The information sharing model of an IS plan is composed of segments, each focusing on one phase of one event, possibly in the context of other past or current events. Each segment defines a list of organizational goals to be achieved via flow-connected tasks. Adding a segment contributes to setting the scope of a plan, because doing so is a prerequisite to adding organizational goals that contribute to the scope.

Set the phase of the event in focus and rate its required/"threshold" level (minor, major, high, very high).

Tasks and flows can be added to the segment.

section.para: When an IS plan is created, it initially contains an untitled segment focusing on the "Responding" phase of the unnamed event. The segment has a single, undefined task and no organizational goals.
A segment can be removed in its entirety, after confirmation. The operation can be undone.

A segment identifies any number of evens as context to the event phase in focus. A segment's context represents what events have occurred or are already occurring when the event phase in focus starts. Events can also be removed from the context.

section.title: Add an organizational goal
section.para: Adding a goal to a segment augments the scope of an IS plan. An organizational goal is either a risk to be mitigated or a gain to be made by an organization (or type of) within the segment where it is listed.

A goal is categorized by choosing from a fixed list of risk or gain types (based on actuarial risk management taxonomies), graded for severity/magnitude, and briefly described with free-form text. Planners can also indicate whether a goal is implicitly achieved with the termination of the segment's event phase (for example, the risk of property damage is terminated when responding to a fire is over, but the risk of litigation is not).

section.title: Adding a secrecy classification system
section.para: A secrecy classification system is a named ordered list of classification names (for example, US Government: sensitive, confidential, secret, top secret). Secrecy classifications are used to set agent clearances, communication channels' security, and the classification levels of elements of information. When an IS plan is created, it defines no secrecy classification system. Planners must first define a secrecy classification system before it can be applied.

section.para: A secrecy classification level can be removed from a secrecy classification system if it is not used anywhere within the plan. Planners can see where a classification level is being used.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The IS procedures of an agent (a person or system) are the list of all tasks assigned to the agent, plus all consequent information sharing commitments as computed from an IS plan in which the agent participates. Planners directly set IS procedures. IS procedures are specified by the definitions of tasks and flows and by the profiles of entities (roles, organizations, agents, places, etc.)
The activities that change the set of IS procedures derived from an IS plan are:

Channels looks at the information needs and information capabilities of tasks to uncover missed opportunities for information sharing (see "Satisfy all needs" in the Commands section).

section.title: Connecting tasks with an information flow
section.para: A planner connects two tasks with an information flow to express the requirement that agents executing the source task commit to share information with agents executing the target task, possibly subject to some restrictions. The information is either produced by or acquired for the execution of the source task, and the information is to be used for the execution of the target task. The same flow appears to the source task in its list of "sends" and to the target task in its list of "receives".

A planner connects a source and target task by doing any of the following:
Opening an information capability of the source-to-be task and identifying or creating the target task in the "To task" field. The target task can be created in situ by selecting "Other..." in the list of candidate target tasks and naming a task that does not yet exist within the segment.
If the flow is between tasks in the same segment, the information need is converted into an information flow; to preserve the information need, the planner must duplicate it and set the source on only the copy or the original. If the flow is between tasks in different segments, the information need is preserved when the flow is created.
Opening an information need of the target-to-be task and identifying or creating the source task in the "From task" field. The source task can be created in situ by selecting "Other..." in the list of candidate source tasks and naming a task that does not yet exist within the segment.
If the flow is between tasks in the same segment, the information capability is converted into an information flow; to preserve the information capability, the planner must duplicate it and set the target on only the copy or the original. If the flow is between tasks in different segments, the information capability is preserved when the flow is created.
Selecting a task with at least one information need and executing the "Satisfy all needs" command on it. The task will be connected with all tasks, across all segments, that have matching information capabilities (if not connected already). The information need and all information capabilities are preserved.

Note that tasks in different segments can be connected by an information flow only if both tasks are both already defined and if an information need of one matches an information capability of the other (an unnamed need matches all capabilities and vice-versa).

section.title: Overview
section.para: In ISP, entities encompass the "static elements" in IS plans that can be unambiguously identified and thus uniquely named. ISP entities are events, phases (of events), agents (people or systems), organizations, roles, places, and communication media (phone, email, etc.) Tasks and flows are not entities because they are neither static (they are what agents do) nor are they uniquely named.

Entities are referenced by name in the definitions of a plan, plan segments, tasks, flows, and in the definitions of other entities. An entity is created the first time it is named and is removed when no longer referenced (immediately if its definition is empty).

Entities can be "actual" or "types". An "actual" entity represents a physical reality, whereas a "type of entity" represents a category of entity. "John Doe" would be an actual agent, whereas "Adult" would be a type of agent. "The United Nations" is an actual organization, whereas "International Governing Body" is a type of organization. And so on. Some kinds of entities can only be types in an IS plan, namely events, phases, roles, and communication media. ISP does not deal with actual events, only with types of anticipated events. Roles, phases, and communication media are inherently categories.

Planners can define (profile) an entity as soon as it is first referenced by giving values to some or all of the entity's attributes. All entities, be they types or actual, have a few attributes in common:
Name - set when first referenced and changeable at any time
Description - short, unstructured text
Tags - a list of tags used for ad hoc grouping of plan elements
Categories - a list of same-kind entity types (an agent is categorized by agent types, a role is categorized by other roles, etc.)
Documentation (attached image, reference document, etc.)

Of these common attributes, categories are particularly important. How an agent, role, place, organization, etc. is categorized can have wide-ranging consequences on how tasks, which are typically defined in terms of entity types, are assigned, and thus on what information sharing commitments are computed from an IS plan. A small change in the categorization of an organization or a role can significantly alter the IS procedures implied in an IS plan.

Most kinds of entities have their own idiosyncratic attributes. For example, an actual organization can have a parent organization, an actual agent can have security clearances, a communication medium might delegate transmissions to other media, etc. The Profiling activities of the ISP Method describe what these attributes are and give their meanings.

Entity profiles are accessed in different ways. An entity's profile can be accessed in Channels
From wherever it is named as part of the definition of a plan element
From the plan's index
From analytical content, such as the compilations of references (for example, all references to the role "Manager")
As a rule, when the name of an entity (or of its kind) appears in blue, it is a hyperlink that, when clicked, opens the profile edit form for that entity.

section.title: Overview
section.para: A number of ISP Method activities do not change the scope of an IS plan nor do they add elements to it, but rather are concerned with improving the plan overall. A plan is improved either by better distributing tasks and flows across segments, by generalizing a task's definition to increase the number of agents that are assignable to it, or by making changes to entity typologies that have wide-ranging effects on the generation of IS procedures.
The Channels-supported, plan-improving activities are:

listitem.para: Moving tasks across segments
Generalizing a task's definition
Changing the categorization of an entity

section.title: Moving tasks across segments
section.para: An IS plan is a collection of segments, each focusing on a specific situation, namely, one phase of one event, possibly in the context of other current or past events. Segments are usually inter-connected both by flows that connect two tasks in different segments, and by the fact that a task in one segment may trigger the situation that is the focus of another segment.

Each segment addresses one or more risks to or opportunities for organizations (goals) for a given situation. As more goals are added to the scope, more tasks are needed to achieve them and to provide needed information. A segment could grow to become quite large and difficult to manage (the flow maps become oversized, the list of completeness issues for the segment become hard to track, etc.)
A solution is to create a new segment, move to the new segment tasks from the large segment that achieve or help achieve a goal, and then remove the goal from the initial segment.

Channels provides a simple and safe mechanism for moving selected tasks all at once to another segment while keeping them connected with their flows. Goals listed in moved tasks are added as needed to the destination segment. Moving tasks is a reversible (undo-able) change.

section.title: Generalizing a task's definition
section.para: Sometimes the assignees of a task are specified too narrowly in the definition of the task, possibly because an organization is identified by name in the definition, or because the role given is too specific. It can also be the case that an IS plan contains multiple tasks, each with the same name but with different, narrowly defined assignee specifications, that could be replaced by a single task with more broadly specified assignees.

However, when two broadly defined tasks are connected by a flow, many of the implied information sharing commitments may be inappropriate. For example, assignees to both the source and target tasks of a flow may be from different organizations (organization types were used to specify task assignees). If the intent was for task assignees to communicate only with co-workers, then a planner must put in a restriction on the flow stating that sharing commitments are only between agents in the same organization. The alternative is to define multiple source and target tasks, each narrowly assigned to members of only one organization (but otherwise identically named pair-wise), and connect them with flows of the same name.

It is an ISP best practice to avoid as much as possible having multiple tasks of the same name in the same segment, except for purposes of overriding tasks and/or flows (see section on Overriding tasks and flows). Generalizing task assignee specifications combined with flow restrictions can greatly reduce the number of tasks and flows in an IS plan, thus making it more manageable and easier to grow.

section.title: Changing the categorization of an entity
section.para: Entity types can themselves be categorized by other entity types. For example, a "Rail station" (a place entity type) can be categorized as a "Building" (another place entity type) and as a "Transit system node" (another place entity type). The categorization of entity types together creates typologies. Because tasks can be defined in terms of entity types (agent types, roles, place types, organization types), small changes to entity typologies can have wide-ranging effects on task assignments, and thus information sharing commitments.

It is highly recommended that planners frequently look up typologies (agent typology, event typology, role typology, etc.) to make sure that each represents an intended conceptualization of the plan's environment and check the assignments calculated for tasks that are affected by the change.

section.title: Commands
section.para: Planners carry out ISP activities in Channels by executing Channels commands. Any change to an IS plan is the result of executing a command. Planners execute commands in Channels whenever they create and remove segments; when they add, cut, copy and paste tasks, needs, capabilities and flows; connect tasks with information flows, disconnect them, add an issue, remove a segment, move tasks across segments, add an intermediate to a flow, etc.

Some commands are directly triggered from “actions” menus within the context of a plan, segment, task, flow, or entity. Other commands are triggered by updating fields in edit forms, or by pressing buttons.
Some commands have simple effects (adding a task, for example) but others can be more complex:

listitem.para: “Disintermediate” removes a task that acts as a middleman in a flow
“Intermediate” adds a middleman task to a flow
“Satisfy all needs” automatically connects information needs of a task to matching but untapped information capabilities from other tasks
"Move tasks" moves one or more tasks from one segment to another, possibly also adding goals achieved by the moved tasks to the target segment

section.para: Complex commands are defined in terms of other commands that are executed completely or not at all. Most commands are reversible and can be undone and redone up and until some planner takes an action that would conflict with the undoing or redoing (for example, anyone removing a task prevents a planner from undoing a change he/she recently did to one of its attributes).

The execution of each command is journaled for replay should the server be interrupted and restarted. It is also recorded and listed in the activities tab in the collaboration panel. Channels makes sure that only one command is being executed on an IS plan at a time, no matter how many planners are working on a plan.

glossdef.para: An agent is a person or system who can be assigned tasks in an information sharing plan based on its profile.

A stand in for agents that need not be individually named and profiled. An example would be “Call center employee”. An agent archetype can play multiple roles and have contact info. An agent archetype can be associated with multiple users.
A transmission that could be received by any number of unidentified agents.
A communication channel specifies a means for the transmission of information. A channel is defined by a transmission medium and, where appropriate, an endpoint.
A channel endpoint specifies where a transmission of information in a given medium is transmitted. An email address, radio channel, or phone number are examples of endpoints.
An element of information is a named component of information. An element of information may be classified and can be accompanied with handling and sourcing data.

An entity in ISP is something that can be referenced by name in the definition of one or more segments, tasks, flows, or entities. Entities are agents, transmission media, events, organizations, phases, places, or roles.
An event in ISP is an anticipated change in the environment of organizations that puts their mission at risk.
A gain is a potential positive outcome for an organization caused by an event.
A goal is the intent by an organization to mitigate a risk to itself or to realize a gain during a phase of an event.
An immediate task starts with an event phase.
An incident is an “outside” event not expected to be caused by a task specified in the Plan.
Actionable data.
An information sharing commitment exists between all agents assigned to a task producing information and all agents assigned to the task consuming it.
An information sharing flow specifies a commitment to share information produced from the execution of a task for use in the execution of another task.

An information sharing plan specifies the procedures that people and systems in roles of responsibility are expected to apply in order to fulfill the missions of their organizations before, during, and/or after certain types of events.
An information sharing procedure for an agent is either a task assigned to the agent or a sharing commitment by the agent.
Specification of the information sharing requirements that expected to be produced by the plan between certain pairs of participating organizations.

An issue is a problem with an element of an information sharing plan or with the plan as a whole. Issues can be about validity (incorrect definition), completeness (something missing), or robustness (plan is failure-prone).
The location or geographical area for which a role is assigned to an agent by an organization.
A transmission targeting multiple, identified agents.
An organization is a group of persons and systems assigned roles of responsibility and organized to accomplish a mission.
A user associated with an agent in an information sharing plan.

A phase is time relative to the initiation or termination of an event. The pre-event phase is the time before the initiation of the event; the co-event phase is the time between initiation and termination of an event; and the post-event phase is the time after termination of an event.
A kind of agent for which the identity is to be provided by its association with a user. A placeholder agent may allow single or multiple user associations.
A planner is a person authorized to modify an information sharing plan.
A policy is an authoritative statement by an organization as to what is allowed, mandated, or forbidden (prohibited).
A role names implied responsibilities assigned by organizations to agents.
A risk is a potential negative outcome for an organization caused by an event.
One phase of one event, possibly in the context of one or more past or current events.

The scope of an information sharing plan is comprised of the events and event phases that are planned for, the organizational goals to be met, the participating organizations, and their participating members.
A segment is a manageable subset of an information sharing plan that should include only the tasks and flows needed to achieve one or more stated goals for one phase of one event.
A task is a purposeful action to be carried out separately or as a team by agents.
A task is assigned to an agent if the agent matches the specifications of who is to execute the task.
A transmission medium is a technological or non-technological means for transmitting information. A transmission medium can support unicast, multicast, or broadcast transmissions.
A transmission targeting a single, identified agent.

or remove the requirement for agreements for the organization.

entry.para: Sharing commitment over unicast channel with unknown endpoint

listitem.para: Make sure that the agent has a known endpoint (address, phone number etc.) for contact via the unicast channel,
or remove the unicast channel from the flow.
Change the agent sharing the information, change the agent receiving the information,
or generalize task specifications to assign multiple agents to either the source or target task.

entry.para: Information flow specified with a channel
Depends on impacted tasks if sharing, else low

listitem.para: Add a channel to the specification.
Start this task with the plan segment
or make it ongoing
or have an incoming sharing flow trigger it.

entry.para: Non-planner user is not a participant

listitem.para: Assign an agent to the user
or unregister the user.

entry.para: No plan segment for event phase

listitem.para: Add a plan segment for phase of event,
remove event from plan scope,
or remove phase from plan scope.
Define a plan segment that responds to it
or remove the event's incident status.

entry.para: Task neither consumes nor produces information

listitem.para: Add information produced
or add received consumed.

entry.para: No known agent in task's named role

listitem.para: Name an agent assigned to the task
or add a participating agent to the plan's scope with this role.
Change the name of information transmitted
or break up the sharing flow.
Remove redundant task
or specify one of the tasks differently.
Remove references to this place,
change its address,
or change its geolocation.

entry.para: Planned-for event may never be caused

listitem.para: Make the event an incident
or make sure at least one task in any segment causes it.

entry.para: Segment’s event phase may never end

listitem.para: If the segment is for a co-event phase, have the event end on its own.
If the plan segment is for a pre-event phase, have the event be an incident or have a task in any segment cause it.
In all cases, have at least one task in the segment terminate the event phase.

entry.para: Segment's event phase may never start

listitem.para: If the segment is for a co-event phase, have the event be an incident, or have the task in another segment cause it.
If the plan segment is for a post-event phase, have the event be self-terminating or have a task in a co-event segment terminate its segment.
Modify the specifications for source and target tasks so that they both imply assignments or add or redefine participating agents to match source and target specifications.
If inadequate clearances are at fault, declassify elements of information or make sure otherwise-committed agents have the required clearances.

entry.para: Task is triggered but never started

listitem.para: If the task starts with its segment (it is permanent or immediate), make sure the event phase of the segment can start (it is a co-event phase of an incident or the phase is started by a task that itself can start),
or else make it so the triggering task can start itself.

entry.para: Unconfirmed job of agent in organization

listitem.para: Confirm the job in the organization’s profile.
Connect need or capability via a sharing flow to/from another task.
Explicitly assign an agent to the task,
profile an agent to match the task specifications,
or modify the task specifications so that it matches at least one participating agent.
Add sharing flows
or extend current sharing flows to include the missing elements of information.
Add a supervisor agent to the job
or remove the job for the employing organization's profile.
Change the postal code
or change the geolocation.

entry.para: Agent is not assigned any task

listitem.para: Explicitly assign agent to a task,
specify a task that matches the agent's profile,
or modify the agent's profile so that it matches one or more task specifications.
Have the task achieve a goal,
end the event phase (if it would end a risk),
or make sure at least one task that it directly or indirectly triggers or critically informs achieves a goal.
Add a channel via which to contact the agent.
Attach an MOU to the sharing agreement
or unconfirm the sharing agreement.
Remove redundant pre- or post-event from the context.

entry.para: Segment context may never come to be

listitem.para: Make event in context an incident,
have a task cause the event,
make event self-terminating (post-event only),
or make a task terminate the event (post-event only).
Add expected element of information
or remove information standard tag.

entry.para: No user participates as this agent agent

listitem.para: Assign a user to the agent.

entry.para: Depends on impacted tasks or medium

listitem.para: Enter a valid address.

entry.para: Agent commits to share with supervisor but has none

listitem.para: Identify the agent’s supervisor
or remove the restriction to share only with a supervisor.

entry.para: There is no intermediate to bypass

listitem.para: Disallow bypassing of intermediate
or make the target task an intermediate by having it re-send the same information.

entry.para: Requirement can not possibly be fulfilled by organization

listitem.para: Add flows to the plan to make satisfaction possible
or change the definition of the requirement.

entry.para: Organization does not have the required number of sending/receiving agents

listitem.para: Modify the plan to achieve the preferred number of required commitments for agents in the organization
or change the definition of the requirement.

entry.para: Requirement is only weakly satisfied by the organization

listitem.para: Modify the plan to achieve the preferred number of required commitments for agents in the organization
or change the definition of the requirement.

entry.para: Location of assigned task not communicated

listitem.para: Add a flow received by the task named containing information about the location
or name the assigned location in the task specification
or make the assigned location be the assigned agent's jurisdiction
or make the assigned location be the jurisdiction of the assigned agent's organization.

entry.para: An agent is employed by the organization without a title

listitem.para: Add a title
or remove the job

section.title: Robustness issues
section.para: The IS plan as currently defined will generate IS procedures that are inherently failure-prone.

entry.para: Flow intended as an alarm is not a notification.

listitem.para: Make the flow a notification.

entry.para: No guarantee information will be received over broadcast channels.

listitem.para: Add an alternate, non-broadcast channel to the flow.

entry.para: Tasks trigger each other in a loop

listitem.para: Break the loop by having one of the triggered tasks not trigger the other.

entry.para: Received element of information is declassified when resent.

listitem.para: Set the classification of the element sent to be at least as high as when it is received,
lower the classification of the received element,
or do not send the classified element.
Remove the channel as an alternative, change the security profile of its medium,
change the secrecy classification of the problematic elements of information,
or remove the classified element(s) of information that exceed the channel's security.
Declassify the information shared,
increase the clearance of the agents assigned to the recipient task,
or change the definition of the task to assign only cleared recipients.

entry.para: Only one source of critical information

listitem.para: Add an alternate source of make the information noncritical.
Provide redundancy for at least one of these critical sharing flows.
Generalize task specifications so that the agent is not the only one assigned to a critical task
or add participating agents to the scope with the same role and organization.
Ease the time constraints the information need
or reduce the time delay for the matching information sharing flow.
Ease the time constraints the information needs
or reduce the time delays of flows disseminating needed elements.

entry.para: Single agent assigned to critical task is bottleneck

listitem.para: Change the specification of the task to allow more agents to be assigned to it
or add participating agents to the scope who will be assigned to the task
or allow more than one participant to represent this agent.

entry.para: Agents assigned to task receive information from too many sources

listitem.para: Remove incoming sharing flows
or add intermediates to spread the incoming communication load

entry.para: Agents assigned to task have too many sharing commitments

listitem.para: Remove outgoing sharing flows
or add intermediates to spread the outgoing communication load

entry.para: Important task has only one assignment

listitem.para: Profile agents so that more than one match the task specifications
or modify the task specifications so that it matches more than one agent
or allow multiple users to participate as this agent.
Change the availabilities of assigned agents so that they leave no gap
or change the specification of the task so that more agents are assigned to fill the gaps.

entry.para: Important task without failure notification protocol

listitem.para: Add a notification conditional on task failure
Require that the information sharing reference the event context
or rename the sharing flow.

entry.para: Agent in sharing commitment not qualified to use transmission medium

listitem.para: Make agent qualified to use the transmission medium
Remove the qualification requirement from the transmission medium
Remove the transmission medium from the flow's channels
Modify the definition of the source or target task so that the unqualified agent is not assigned to it.

entry.para: Agent can not fulfill sharing responsibilities from flow

listitem.para: Make agent qualified to use the transmission medium
If flow is to all, make sure the agent can fulfill all commitments from flow
If flow is to any, make sure the agent can fulfill at least commitment from flow

entry.para: Requirement is only weakly satisfied by organization

listitem.para: Modify the plan to achieve the preferred number of required commitments for agents in the organization
or change the definition of the requirement.
